Da Flora is one of the many hidden gems that are scattered about San Francisco, making this city a foodie's paradise.

Let's start with the looks. No, the decor is not trendy and sexy, nor should it be. Hardwood tables and mis-matched chairs. A floor that was last laid in probably the 70s or 80s. This place looks like it was lifted out of Venice and dropped in North Beach.

Don't you dare ask for a Chardonnay or a Cab. You will drink Italian wines only, and more importantly, you will drink what the owner opened for the evening. She'll bring out the bottle to show you, but don't argue with her because she'll probably kick you out.

The menu is handwritten, presumably based on what they were able to pick up at the market that day.

I had a special Hungarian crepe stuffed with chicken livers covered by a paprika sauce and it was amazing. My pasta with seafood was cooked perfectly. I appreciated the European portion sizes instead of the typical USA-one-dish-feeds-four heaping bowls of pasta.

Go here for the food, hospitality, and to hang out with true San Franciscans. If you want big white plates with huge menus and Thievery Corporation pumping in the background, then face the fact you're just a snob (not a food snob, but a regular snob) and you just don't know how good cookin' should taste. :)
author: Mark A.

description:
I'm sorry to say I was disappointed and won't go back.  While others have complained about the service, that wasn't the weakness we saw.  It was all about the food and price tag.

When we ordered the appetizers (gnocchi and asparagus), they came out in 5 minutes.  So, they clearly weren't made to order and that was apparent in the taste.  Bad start.

The main we got was a risotto and something else (I don't even remember).  It was just ok.  Nothing to write yelp about.

The wine we ordered was ok, but expensive - $40.  There were not a lot of affordable bottles on the menu.  And the handwritten menu was full of mistakes, like leaving 0's out of the price.  How charming.

Total price tag was $80-$100 for two.  I could have cooked a better meal for less than $20, and used organic, local food.

Rose Pistola and Osteria Del Forno are two of my favorite places in NB.
author: Sameer D.

description: Still outstanding food and great wine, they continue the tradition of serving special dishes with a personal touch, and spot-on choices of wine.  A local treasure!
author: Susan M.

description: Best focaccia bread I've had in my life! Light & airy, with a satisfying crispy saltiness. I had high hopes for the rest of dinner based on this strong start and while it was tasty, nothing could compete. We had the sweet potato gnocchi starter. The cream sauce was decadent and delicious with bacon and sage, but the gnocchi themselves were dense. Next the squid ink tagliatelle was also decent, but with a tomato base it lacked the salty and citrus flavor profile that goes so well with the black pasta. Chicken paprikash, though an odd pick for a Italian meal, was highly recommended by our server as the owner is also Hungarian. This dish also featured gnocchi, this version regular potato, seared, light, and delicious. Sadly, the sauce was a bit bland. On the plus side the decor is beautiful, elegant but simple. While the dining room is open it's also quiet and intimate, perfect for conversation. The owner also came over to chat. Overall it was a great experience, though sadly the food isn't crave-able enough for me to return.
author: Robin A.

description:
That bite of Gnocchi melts in your mouth and you reach for your glass of Italian wine and bring it to your lips. Your eyes stare past the large white melting candles in their stand and out the window to watch, for a moment, Saturday evening pouring into night. 

The rent I have to pay to live like a college student, the buses that are never on time, the beggars constantly pulling my coat tail, all of that is worth it because I can walk to places like this and enjoy them anytime my income allows. 

Both the owner and waitress discussed with us which bottle of wine would go well with our orders. The character made the experience more memorable, not sure why everyone is so upset because they didn't receive a big fake butt kissing. 

--Mamma Da Flora, as long as you keep making food that tastes that good you can treat me however you want.
author: Slim P.

description:
Living in the neighborhood I never went.  Dangit!  My ex-landlord insisted we go and celebrate my moving to the East Bay (that sounds bad, he really does like me, hence the dinner at this phenominal place).

I'm going to copy this statement from another post: "gnocchi with pancetta was A.M.A.Z.I.N.G." - holy crap.  Everyone at the table agreed with the statement uttered by the 12 year old with an impressive palet, "it's like heaven".  That was a shared appetizer.  The cod bruschetta was phenominal (I'm picky about fish FYI).   I had a very simple pasta with butternut squash and kale, but simple and amazing it was.   The Pinot Noir from Hungary was a fun surprise and a complete delight, I cannot wait to go back here!!
author: Shelby C.

description: Had a dreamy night here on my birthday - possibly the best birthday dinner of my life; though I have to confess that the company factored in. Bottom line is, I grew up with my Grandma Carmella's gnocchi as the gold standard. I've been on a quest to find gnocchi that measured up my entire life, including the 9 months I spent studying in Italy. The sweet potato gnocchi here measures up; in fact, if I were being entirely honest I might even say it surpasses my grandma's (please don't hate me, Grandma!). In addition to that, Da Flora is the epitome of romantic. The lighting, the paint, the restroom, the hand written menus,  the tables - all fabulous. Thank you for an evening that will always be among my favorite memories!
author: About A.

description:
Truly a gem! A small, cozy place with a small menu of food made well. 

The menu changes often, but we tried a couple of the staples, and something new.

*  The sweet potato gnocchi with bacon - perfect pillowy deliciousness. 
*  Hungarian pork - nothing I'd particularly crave - but it definitely has that homemade taste.
* We also had the pappardelle with duck- soft pasta, tender duck, savory sauce. It actually made me like peas. This was the best thing we ordered. (next to the focaccia)
* Oh focaccia, how I love thee..
author: Candy C.

description:
We've eaten at Da Flora's several times over the years, and until last night I would have given them 4 stars consistently.  Bread excellent, fabulous even; ditto gnocchi and desserts.  I thought the entree was so-so, consistently.   Also, as noted by other reviewers, the two women running the place lacked a little something in the area of class and good manners.

We went back to Da Flora's on Friday night.  We were surprised and saddened that the gnocchi wasn't delightful anymore.  The "pillows" were heavy.  Dessert was very ordinary.  The spinach manicotti was dreadful.  One of the women running the place was friendly (for a change) and the bread was spectacular, so it gets two stars.  But, we've concluded they must have hired a new chef, and it's no longer worth a visit.  Very disappointing for an expensive meal.
author: Qween E.

description:
I've been trying to go to this restaurant forever. We're locals in the neighborhood and have been dying to try it for over a year - swearing each time that this would be the spot to celebrate our next big occasion. Finally the stars aligned and we made it for my birthday a few weeks ago.

It was worth the wait. The sweet potato gnocchi with pancetta was A.M.A.Z.I.N.G. We had to have two orders. We also had lamb ragu with fresh pasta, trout, and chocolate lava cake. I ate to the point of pain, but it was so good...totally worth it.

It's definitely not a budget meal, so we'll only return for special occasions, but it's a great spot to look forward to. My only improvement would be adding a few wines that are a bit more affordable and/or by the glass options. Other than that, everything was perfect!
author: Megan C.

description:
Cute little Italian place with pleasant homey service.  The ladies were quirky and had a nice sarcastic twist which I appreciate every now and then.

The food was a different story.  I thought my entree was quite bland, I just remember the pasta was Tagatelle, but because it was so bland, I just can't remember what the heck was mixed in with it. . .

My girlfriends' dishes, though, were slightly better.  One got some eggplant pasta, which was good.  The other got some squid ink pasta that she claimed gave her food poisoning the next day.

On the upside, I did like the fact that they give you a side of freshly grated cheese when serving the pasta entrees.
author: Christina L.

description:
Da Flora is quite unique. The atmosphere is quaint & friendly. Several people that walked through the door were greeted with a hug from the owner. They prefer cash & ask that you don't use your cell phones (I'm a fan of the no cell phone usage during dinner btw). The menu changes daily, but the one thing that is always available is the homemade focaccia bread. This was hands down the BEST focaccia I've ever had. I would go back just for the bread alone. It was crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside, had a hint of salt, and was lightly coated in olive oil. We ate two full plates of it between the two of us, and for once in my life I didn't feel guilty about the carbs because they were worth every bite. We had the stuffed artichoke for a starter. I expected it to be served warm, instead of cold, but it was still really good. The crunch of the breadcrumbs and the tender artichoke heart was a great contrast. My dinner companion had the halibut served over asparagus. He thought it was a little bland. I had the risi bisi: risotto with fresh peas. Great flavors & texture. Not too rich, and very filling. Overall I really enjoyed the meal and the ambiance. The prices were on the higher side, but fairly average for NB. Go try the focaccia!!   

For the full review please visit:
http://consumingcolumbus.blogspot.com/2013/04/da-flora.html
author: Elizabeth C.

description: With so many fabulous restaurants in San Francisco, I can't imagine why anyone would put up with a grumpy, unwelcoming place. The food was nothing special. They don't like you to pay with credit cards.
author: Robin S.

description:
"May I have a glass of chianti?"
"Tonight, I'm pouring a sangiovese."

That's the kind of restaurant Da Flora is..."Welcome to dinner....this is what we're serving." Gotta love the freedom of no choice!!!

Well, there were amazing choices on the menu.  A few, but each one more decadent than the next...gnocchi was incredible. I had the duck livers for my entree. Yes, duck livers -- and they were melt-in-your-mouth wonderful. No joke...if this restaurant can make duck liver so scrum-diddly-umptuous, I can't wait to try some rigatoni. Well, if they're serving it next time I go.
author: Kat M.

description: Popped in a couple months ago on a Saturday night and we were fortunate enough to be seated immediately. Excellent food and wine. Great service and ambiance. Can't wait to go back.
author: Meesh S.

description:
Da Flora is an absolute gem!  The changing daily menu of innovative Northern Italian cuisine, charming ambiance and personal touches by the proprietors makes this Venetian restaurant shine in a neighborhood overrun by touristy Italian restaurants.  

I was looking for a great date night restaurant in North Beach, and I remembered the stellar reviews for Da Flora on Check Please Bay Area.  When I walked into the restaurant, I felt like I had been transported to a cozy, little spot in Europe that had been in operation for decades.  I was even more impressed when I opened the menu and found a handwritten list of primo and secondo dishes.    

We started with the sweet potato gnocchi which was served with the sage sauce instead of bacon sherry sauce since I'm pescatarian.  It was delicious as a vegetarian dish, so the dish definitely deserves the title of their house special.  For our main courses, we had the trout over zucchini and the squid ink risotto.  I've never been a huge fan of squid ink dishes, but the creamy texture and spicy sauce of the risotto literally stopped our conversation mid-sentence when we tasted it.

My only regret is that we didn't have time to try their dessert, which is made my the same baker who does their amazing focaccia bread.  I can't wait to go back and experience more of their menu.
author: Kimberly J.

description:
This restaurant is the best high-end Italian you will find in the city.  The food is excellent, the wine is excellent, and the atmosphere is a pure delight and a welcome escape from the sterile, flat-screen peppered trend traps that seem to be taking over the universe these days.  I am a concierge, and I regularly recommend Da Flora to my guests, especially when they are planning a birthday or anniversary dinner.  Not one of my guests has ever been disappointed by the cuisine or by the service there.  

I will say that Da Flora is very strict with their reservation policy (as one would expect of any high-end restaurant), so if you do arrive late without calling ahead or if you walk in expecting to be immediately seated without a reservation, you will likely not have a pleasant outcome.  The reasonable and respectful thing to do would be to make a reservation ahead of time and arrive on time.  It is true that the owners can be brusque at times, but they are running a small independent business, and if they have other people arriving at set times, they can't just give up their tables to you if you arrive late with no advance notice or if you walk in off the street expecting immediate service just because there happen to be a few tables empty at that particular moment.  

I have found that the owners generally tend to reflect the attitudes that are presented to them, and while this might not be the most ingratiating approach to adopt in the field of hospitality, it is as it is, so all patrons might do well to keep it in mind.

A direct response to a couple of ratings below: if you want or need something in life and find you are not getting it, ask for it.  I have never seen anyone at this restaurant ignore anyone on purpose, but when there are two owners and one server covering a whole roomful of people, it isn't suprising that every so often something small gets overlooked.  What I want to know is, what kind of person sits passive-aggressively back without saying a word for 40 minutes while his water glass sits unfilled?  I guess the same kind of person who would taunt a fellow reviewer for misspelling "potato" when he can't even spell "gnocchi", after talking himself up as the world's biggest foodie for a couple of paragraphs.  

Anyway, no more venting--this restaurant is among the very best in the city, and it is a must-visit for every local and for any discerning tourist.  I have nothing but respect and appreciation for Da Flora.
author: Tara D.

description: A little piece of Italy transported to north beach. Really felt like I was in a quaint restaurant in italy. Food was good, the fig and prosciutto was amazing. Service was slow but other than great.
author: Linda H.

description:
In a nutshell: pretty good food, lousy service.

We came to Da Flora on the recommendation of  my mother, who stumbled upon it while staying nearby and liked it. As locals, we rarely venture to North Beach for food because most restaurants are so touristy. This is not one of those places, and the promise of sweet potato gnocchi with bacon lured us in.

We arrived to our reservation a bit late, and though the restaurant was half empty, the owner (whose nickname from other reviews I shall not repeat) looked pained but allowed us to sit anyway. Fine. Our eyes lit up and our mouths watered when we glimpsed the listing of the gnocchi, and this was immediately forgotten.

Now, this is one of those Italian places with a Primi and Secondi menu. I never feel obligated to order one from column A and one from column B. This can be a lot of food, and do I really want two pasta dishes? Maybe I want a salad and a pasta and not a meat dish. Or maybe I don't consider pasta an appetizer. But when I tried to order the Caesar Salad and the gnocchi (as did others in our party), I was informed that the gnocchi was an appetizer, and she'd come back when we figured out what we really wanted. Odd. 

Well, guess what? That's what we really wanted. So when she came back, we repeated our order. She got that pained look again, and said that she'd give some of us a full size (read: twice as expensive) portion of the gnocchi. Later, we had the opportunity to compare the size of the "full" portion and the normal portion. Double the price for 20% more gnocchi is not what I wanted to order.

But the fun doesn't stop there. We wanted to get wine, but they only had them listed by the bottle. So we asked if they had wines by the glass. She told us we should get a bottle. Because... some of us want red and some of us want white. So, instead of getting the list, she picked wine for us (which could be charming, had we not already encountered being told what to order), all without mentioning the price - $12 each as it turned out.

The rest of the meal was fine. Well, except that we never got any water. We ordered dessert and ended up with a $160 bill for the 3 of us, so it's not like we came in intending to be el cheapo. But we came away feeling like they thought we were trying to short change them and looked down upon because we're 20somethings (Guess what? Our money is good too). I understand that it's a small place and they have limited seating. So have a minimum per person or prix fixe. But don't tell me what I can and can't order or try to guilt me into ordering more or something different than what I want. 

In some way, it was a valuable experience. I won't tolerate such rudeness in any restaurant again. Had there been any other good restaurants in the area that we knew about nearby, we would have just left at the start. As it was, at least we got a good story out of it.
author: Dan F.

description:
I am so grateful that we had a very pleasant experience at Da Flora, everyone of the staff was pleasant.  Plus they make no bones about who they are and how they do business.  Fortunately, small portions are fine for me.

We had our water glasses refilled.  They accommodated us letting us use my special Early Girl tomatoes that I reduce until they become meaty and are redolent of fresh basil and garlic with EVO OIL (it takes hours to make them).  They even gave us extra of their excellent focaccia. Plus, we
had a bottle of our own wine that my friend makes ~ I know they like to sell their own Italian wines but Michael makes fine wines.  The glasses they provided were very elegant and high quality.

Porchette with a creamy tuna and a lemon~caper creme sauce was perfection on my plate, really a visual and gustatory pleasure.  The flavor was pork at its finest, sweet and succulent.  Michael's salad of arugula and fennel was tossed with a "champagne" (note lower case) vinegar and Cara Cara oranges with Romano salato.  Delizioso and fresh, bright tastes.

The M Man opted for the squid risotto with squid ink so it was quite black and tasty.  My duck livers were overdone and ate them as is even though
they would have been grand if cooked medium rare.  The polenta was
very good and crispy, the way I like it.

Our desserts were quite lovely, mine was a combo of pistachios and almonds in a cake like timbale.  M had a plum tart that was fab.

The ambiance of da Flora is extremely European, painted a deep red with lots of pictures on the walls. It is an intimate place, small and comforting with that feeling of days gone by.  They have 4 "Fortuny" type hanging lamps that are reminiscent of Venezia.  The chairs are the first thing I noticed, beautifully carved, warm dark wood that are substantial.  Our waitperson said they were custom made in Seattle (If I remember right)  ~ I was truly impressed with the quality.

If the duck livers had not been overcooked, I would have given them

F O U R   S T A  R S........  Maybe they will get them next time.
author: ELINOR H.

description: This place is a real find. The ambiance is charming. The staff delightful. The food is spectacular. A must go
author: Tina F.

description:
This place is YUM.

I was really excited to see if the service was as bad as other yelpers mentioned, but we were really pleased with the service we were given.

Their sweet potato gnocchi was heaven and the reason why I soo want to go back. If you ever go, get this!
I have had homemade pasta before and definately prefer that over the regular blah you get elsewhere. This is delicious food, definately worth trying.

The only disappointment was the dessert, we had some kind of chocolate cake and it was just okay. I still give it 5 stars, will come back again and again!
author: Haley S.

description:
I had been meaning to eat here for a long time because I kept passing by it and it looks really cute from the outside. It is dimly lit, red color themed, there are candles, and it just looks very cute and romantic.

Unfortunately, the food and service did not live up to the atmosphere. The menu is handwritten, and I can understand where that would be charming, but when it is dimly lit and the writing is small and calligraphic, it was just very difficult to read. They were also out of 2 of the things I wanted, which I just didn't expect. I ended up with a meal that was mediocre and the service just took forever. In fact I wasn't even sure what exactly I ordered because I couldn't read the menu. I could see the owner just sitting down and chatting with our waitress and we were waiting for what felt like forever for the menu, each course, and the bill. I guess a part of me thinks it's forgivable because that's just how things are done in Italy, but being in SF, I definitely expect better service. 

Even though I enjoyed the atmosphere, the food and service would prevent me from going back.
author: Diana C.

description:
Mmmm mmmm!!! I love this place! Small little corner.
Very tasty. Delicious starter bread and oh my god. I'm pretty sure everything on their menu is amazing. Expensive, but goood.
 I just love North Beach in general.
Good for dates.
author: Alyssa Z.

description:
Get your mind right! A dinner at Daflora's is stepping into Flora and Marybeth's and Jennifer's (the Chef), Italian Social Club with home cooked Venetian delicacies and no wise guys but maybe Wide guys. This is European and one dines over several hours.  A romantic room with North Beach passing by the large windows and not for catching a 6PM quickie before the 7PM show.  A place to hold hands, name a baby, propose.  Dip the homemade foccacia into the gnocchi cream sauce, taste the garlic, savor the Italian wine suggested by Flora.  Celebrity Chefs, this is what you always wanted to do before you got big-time. The first place we will dine when I get back from the 10th century in A-Stan. 

Made it back from A-Stan with all my pieces and had my first SF dinner here.  Like a time warp it was as though I never left and all the memories of the Intercontinental Hotel burning and guests being executed room by room  fell away with hugs from Flora and the first bite of the fresh baked foccacia glistening with olive oil.  Tim and Cathy
author: Tim L.

description:
I hate to give this a place a five as I found the service to be lackluster, however, it is so rare to find a truly good pasta place that I'm ok suffering through said service.

The food here was the best italian I have eaten in SF by a wide margin. Truly great pasta and a very strong wine list to match. Frankly if the management were more welcoming I would eat here more often, as it is I come once a year.
author: Pierre C.

description:
We decided to come here randomly from a recommendation from a friend. We were going to Cobb's Comedy Club after dinner for a show and decided to give Da Flora a try since it was nearby. 

Right when you get in, you get a quaint cozy-home feeling. It is a small restaurant that I'm assuming is family run. 

Appetizers-
- Sweet Potatoe Gnocchi- Very good, chewy and fluffy at the same time. However, we were debating between this and the waitress semi-forced us to order this.
- Salted Cod- really yummy as well. The cod was perfectly complimented by the buttered toast. 

-Fresh Tagiatelle w/ Crab- DELCIOUS! The sauce wasn't has heavy as expected and there were chunks and chunks of freshly cracked crab. 
- Meyer Lemon Risotto- not as "lemony" as I expected, but stillv ery very rich. 
- Braised Lamb- very tender, but weird because the taste reminded us all of movie theater popcorn. Yeah......
- Spicy Sausage Penne- good, but didn't really stand out too much to me. 

The service here is very good as they are very attentive and have a lot of passion about their food. They have an impressive display of wine as well, but when we debated ordering by the glass or bottle, the waitress decided that we would get a $45 bottle of wine and walked off without us confirming. Turns out that the wine wasn't bad, but it wasn't good either. And when we looking around the rest of the restaurant, every other table had the SAME bottle of wine. It was like they had an overstock of that particular wine and decided to make everyone buy a bottle.
author: lauren j.

description:
Their foccacia bread & sweet potato gnocchi with bacon were absolutely unforgettable!!   Unfortunately, so was the offensive service and attitude we received from Flora and the rest of their wait staff (as many others have pointed out).  Definitely the worst I've ever experienced. EVER. We will not be going back, and will not be recommending this restaurant to any of our friends.  

If you're not one of their regulars who drop hundreds of dollars on mostly-mediocre food and wine here, then you are treated with contempt and disgust, if you're even "lucky" enough to get seated at a table by them (I saw them turn away an elderly lady in a wheelchair who arrived late for her reservation, even though there were plenty of tables open and it was still early for dinner!).
author: Anna L.

description:
Wow! Tiny restaurant (12 tables), handwritten menu, incredible service and some of the best food you will ever eat. Diverse selection of starters and entrees and a sophisticated wine list. Incredibly romantic atmosphere.

The gnocchi are little puffs of heaven.
author: Megan B.

description: A wonderful intimate Italilan restaurant with an amazing, unique menu. The sweet potato gnochi is amazing! WIne list is primarly from Italy and surrounding regions with some excellent choices. Staff is very friendly and attentive. The food is fabulous!
author: Andy B.

description: I have found the Holy Grail - quote from my dinning companion and the absolute truth!  The food was AMAZING!  The service and space was just as good.  Can't believe I have walked by this Jem so many times and never stopped in.  The bread was so delicious it brought tears it was so amazing.
author: Naja J.

description:
This place is sooooooo good!  I love their attention to detail and all the personal touches like writing the menu out in their own handwriting.  Last time I was here my uncle & I both had the gnocchi 1st course and then the sole. They recommended the perfect bottle of wine to go with it all. And the dessert... these thin, chocolate, heart-shaped cookies, sandwiched together with a touch of cream...YUM!  It's small, intimate & red...candles everywhere.
I forgot to mention the bread...omg...try not to fill up on it! Service is always attentive & they go out of their way to make you feel at home. Enjoy!
author: Kelly V.

description:
I adore this place.  My sweetie and I have been here with a small group, with family, for our anniversary...and it is always amazing.  The atmosphere is WONDERFUL, the gnocchi is STUNNINGLY GOOD, the wines are DIVINE....

This place is not your typical North Beach mediocre italian slop with froofy service.  It's down to earth yet fancy enough to feel special and the food is made with such care and originality.   This place is a favorite for sure.
author: Pamela W.

description: I had dinner at Da Flora Saturday night  with my wife and a small group of friends.    It was a  perfect evening in every way.    Every table was filled  with happy locals, and Flora and Mary Beth were in full flourish.  I'm not much of a food critic but I know a great meal when I have one.  Everyone in my party  ordered a different entree (scallops, cannelloni, squid risotto) and each was perfectly prepared and absolutely delightful.  Flora selected a Hungarian wine for us and regaled the table with a 16th century fable  from the village the wine was made in.  Da Flora is a local treasure -- as another Yelper aptly put it:  "submit to the ladies."
author: Steven G.

description:
Here is the deal.

I have not had an Italian meal this good since I was in Sicily.  This recommendation and five stars is purely for the food and decor of the restaurant. 

Atmosphere:
Very small corner restaurant on Columbus. Very rare to have a decent place to eat on this street.  The place has a very parisian feel to it, with small tables that have a unique piece of art or candle sitting on top and wine lined walls. 

Service:
As much as I love the food, I find the two servers that are always there (I believe one is Flora herself) slightly rude.  They can be short, especially if you ask questions about the food.  But for me, it is never enough to ruin the taste of the experience.

Tips:
Appetizer- the potato gnocchi is truly amazing. 
All the pasta dishes are made that day and full of fresh ingredients. Good portions too.

Bummer:
There is not a bottle of wine on the menu that is under $35. And all the glasses are at least $10.  Which leaves you with a pretty hefty bill, considering the main courses are all $21 and above.

Parking:
Take the Stockton 30 bus, or park on the cross streets, such as Filbert or Greenwich. There is also a parking garage on the opposite corner of the restaurant.  http://en.parkopedia.com/parking/garage/filbert_st/san_francisco/

Despite the price and the slightly rude service, the food makes it all worth it. 

You've just been yelped in.
author: Aaron A.

description:
I kinda hate to review this place as I don't want it to be so crowded I can never dine here again... but it's not so much a secret place anymore and the fact is... I love Da Flora! 
I've been here several times and I always, always get the sweet potato gnocchi... they are as good as everyone says! Getting those are an automatic, but EVERYTHING is good. The seasonal salads, the roasted meat entrees, the desserts... I always leave happy. The decor is so charming- I love the candles right as you walk in- and the service is great. Maybe if I showed up late, were talking on my cell phone during dinner, or acted without decorum (in the innumerable ways people do these days), I might think they were a little cold, but I do not behave that way, so they are perfectly cordial to me. They also have a great wine list- I like to order my meal, tell them my price range and have them choose- I'm never disappointed. 
PS- they prefer cash, so I always hit the ATM beforehand (they're many along Columbus)
author: Terry M.

description:
How could this not have been one of the best meals I've ever had?

I am not fortunate enough to have had the Sweet Potato Gnocchi. It was sold out by the time my reservation took place.

I had a butternut squash risotto that was to die for. For desert I had a pistachio cake that was also delicious. In the last few years I've lost my sweet tooth, but for cake that good? I'll bloody well find it again! 

For the wine, our choice was sold out and we were recommended the Masetto Nero and it was absolutely perfect.
author: John R.

description:
Quite possibly the worst service I have ever experienced at a restaurant in my life.  

We had called in 4 days prior to make a reservation for 8 for Saturday night.  They told us it would be no problem and they would put two tables together for us.

When we arrive at the restaurant promptly on time for our reservation, the women who work there told us our TABLES were ready.  They were putting us at two separate tables for 4 on complete opposite sides of the restaurant.  We told her that we made our reservation days ago for 8 and they said it would be no problem to accommodate our party.  The women didn't care whatsoever.  They told us we can sit at separate tables or go elsewhere.

We fought this with them for literally 25 minutes before finally they begrudgingly agreed to put two tables together and let us sit together.  Before they made the final decision to let us sit together, we heard one of the women say "these people are not going to leave so we have to just let them sit".  

Finally after our party is sat down after standing outside in the rain for 25 minutes, the waiter comes up to us immediately and says "OK folks, to catch up on lost time we need you to order right now."  She handed us menus and forced us to order without looking at the menu for more than 10 seconds.  

After we are done with our meals the waiter tells us that they need our table as soon as possible and essentially forces us out the door.  

As a group we all agreed this was the most atrocious service we have ever received in our lives.  It was absolutely outrageous the way we were treated.  

The sad part is the food was actually delicious.  So if you happen to be looking to be treated like human garbage for a night by a bunch of Viking women, then this is the place for you.  Otherwise avoid this place at all costs.
author: Dan L.

description: I selfishly want to keep this place to myself, but I will share it because they deserve the business. My lady and I live in LA, but every time we are in SF, it's a MUST for us to eat at Da Flora. This is a wonderful mom and pop restaurant. It's the best Italian food we've ever had and I'm Italian! The bread before the meal is so warm and fresh and perfectly oiled and spiced, it could be a meal in itself.  We always get Mary Beth as our server and she is amazing. Eating here is like having homemade food that your Italian grandmother would make. Jen the chef is not just a chef, she's an artist and the menu is handwritten and Jen changes it regularly, so we're always looking forward to what delicious creation she'll come up with next.  You must try the sweet potato Gnocci; it's out of this world! The ambience, the intimate environment, the people, the food.....you get the whole package here!
author: Fred M.

description: I wish this place was in my backyard but alas it's across the country. Great place for a special romantic dinner. Very pricey but worth it. Dinner for two, bottle of wine and splitting dessert ran us $165 but it was worth every penny. The amazing soft foccaica to start was only improved upon the waitress reloading our plates. The sweet potato gnocchi was crazy good. I highly recommend!
author: Maura D.

description:
PROS - 
Hand-written menu.
Old World Family Feel.
Amazingly delicious, fresh food.  Pork ragu with fresh pappardelle pasta was out of this world.  
Wine list to match.
Singing happy birthday and sharing birthday cake with everyone, courtesy of one of the regular patrons.
Tiny romantic room.

CONS - 
Tiny romantic room - feeling like everyone can hear you, which they can if you don't whisper.
Tough / hard to read service.
author: Monica S.

description:
So yum. I'm so full.

I went here tonight a bit skeptical about going to get another overpriced, mediocre Italian restaurant in North Beach.

We started with the sweet potato gnocchi w/ pancetta. The best gnocchi ever. Perfectly cooked so the texture was so good. The sweet potato was subtle and the sauce with pancetta was a perfect complement... yum. 

I had the pappardelle pasta with lamb bolognese sauce. The pappardelle is hand made and was again, perfectly cooked - not too el dente, and not mushy; it had the perfect homey texture. So good. The sauce was flavorful and well-seasoned. The pasta was piping hot and it just tasted fresh. I'm sure it was a zillion calories, but the dish wasn't greasy. Perfect sauce to pasta ratio too. This is the best bowl of pasta I've had in a very, very long time.

We had the strawberry rhubarb crisp w/ vanilla ice cream. Yum. Again, fresh, flavorful and not too sweet or rich and oily. Just delicious.

I do think this place is a little expensive... but worth it. You can tell that the food is homemade with quality ingredients. A glass of wine (by the glass), shared gnocchi dish, main pasta and shared dessert will run you nearly $50! So good.... 

Yes, the service was a little rough around the edges, but not nearly as awful as some other reviewers described. I found the service fine and the staff polite. My friends had dined here before and expressed that they were intimidated by the owners. As soon as we stepped in, my friends became so behaved, overly polite and timid. haha. 

I will definitely come back here. ymmm
author: Cindy Y.

description: Ok walked into the place on a Saturday night at 9:30 pm and was turned away with 5 available tables. To add salt to the wound, it was my birthday dinner. DO WE NOT LIVE IN A MAJOR US CITY?  I now give up on this place, the food is amazing but Shrek, owner #1, and the other fat lady provide the most horrible service that I just cannot go there ever again
author: Laura D.

description:
Not sure how I just discovered Da Flora this past weekend after 7 years in SF, but thank god I did. Absolutely gorgeous, small, quaint, romantic setting. Caring, attentive and expert owners who add flavor to an already flavorful experience with humor and tales of Italy. And the food? Perfect.  

Highly recommend this spot for a perfect, memorable and warm night with your love or your favorite group of lovelies. Can't wait to go back.

Re: the below comments on the staff, I obviously had a great experience, even complimentary glasses of muscat at the end of the meal so I can't comment on their experiences - but I would advise expecting a more Italian experience, e.g., big personalities and not your usual American dining staff.
author: sarahjane s.

description:
We were looking for a restaurant for our 6th year anniversary dinner.
I .... kind of ....   wanted to eat the fried chicken at Miller's East Coast Deli again. But having an anniversary dinner at Miller's is kind of .... wrong idea? And kind of depressing location at night. I see more vomit & urine smell or sweet & sour on the street, more homeless people. I don't mind to go to a gay bar after but... 

I want Polk Street Clean! Especially from Sacramento St down to Eddy St.

This place was on a TV show calls "Check Please".
My GF saw the show and told me that, in the show, all 3 guys liked the place.
I said, " We gotto find out."
So we made a reservation at Da Flora.
We always walking by but never been here before.
An antique lookin' place.
My GF worried the service because reading Yelp reviews.
But we got to have the "Gnocchi".

Our reservation was at 6pm.
We got there few minutes after but we were the 1st customers.
I saw  "NO ON PROP 8 " sign on the window.
I said to myself, " I already like this place."

It's a cozy restaurant.
Handwritten menu was interesting.
Great wine list. $38 to three hundred some dollars for a bottle.
We had the wine of the day, by a glass= 11 bucks= nice.
Olive oily focaccia bread was great. 
The sweet potato gnocchi was awesome.
Cesar salad, thin sliced roast pork appetizer and penne all'amatriciana.

When we were ordering,
The waitress said, " Have you been here before?"
We said, " No."
She said, " OK, because our dishes are small size."
My GF said, "is it enough for us?"
She said, " Yeah, for a light dinner."

We were stuffed.
We had to pass on dessert but it was a great wonderful anniversary dinner.

Btw, about the bathroom...there are 2 doors. if you close the inside door, there is a large full size 6 foot long x 20 inches width mirror behind the door that you'll see your self-sitting on the can. This was the 1st time for me watching my self sitting on a can doing it. And I found out my bad habit that I scratch my crotch when I'm sitting on a can.
Thanks to the mirror, I won't do it again.  It was disgusting watching "it".
author: Nobu K.

description:
Are you kidding me with this?  I wanted to dry hump the gnocchi, since it was so f*cking good.  But restaurants tend to frown on that sort of thing.  So, I stayed in control until I got home.  

Hello, new lover!  You are the gnocchi at Da Flora.
author: Kiki G.

description: Definitely one of my more enjoyable dinner experiences in San Francisco. I haven't had a bad meal along Columbus yet, but this place does enough to distinguish itself from all of the other Italian restaurants. They definitely make an effort to create an intimate dining atmosphere and provide very personal service to each table.  One of the standouts on the menu for me was the butternut squash gnocchi (if you're into that sort of thing) but really everything I tasted that night was great. The bread comes out drizzled in olive oil ready to go to. One interesting thing to note is that because they use hand pressed Ventian menus, the appetizers and entrees must be ordered together to avoid getting any food debris on the delicate material. Definitely recommended for a date night or family dinner (although it doesn't seem that kid-friendly)
author: Taylor C.

description:
There are very few reasons why I'd ever venture up to North Beach on a weekend night. Scores of obnoxious drunk drivers in SUVs is not one of them. Da Flora, however,  is.

Romantic, cozy, off the tourist track, it really was such nice surprise compared to the zoo known as "A North Beach Saturday Night".  We had later reservations (9pm) and by that time, much of the food was already out. I ended up getting the gnocchi appetizer served as an entree, which although good, ended up being too rich for as a full serving. However, we also ordered the scallops and they really were amazing...and I don't even LIKE scallops. Wine was perfectly paired and the butterscotch pot de creme was a perfect cap to the meal.  

The prices are a little steep, but I'm keeping the four star rating - primarily because the bathroom reminded me of  the bathrooms in my grandfather's old  Victorian, perched high on an SF hill and perpetually enshrouded in fog. I don't get nostalgic about many things, but my grandfather's house is an exception. So yes, Da Flora keeps it four star rating for an entirely irrational reason. But when is enjoyment of the senses ever a purely rational experience?
author: Umami Y.

description:
This is my new favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  It made me feel like I was in Venice.

The chef is absolutely fearless.  She uses ingredients that might scare some people off, but those who are brave and strong will be amply rewarded.  You will not be greeted by a mini-skirted hottie, you will not have a simpering waiter who tells you his name, you will not get exactly the same menu as the place up the street. What you will get is amazing unique food and, if you're courteous, friendly, unhurried service.

They started by giving us a plate of oil-drizzled homemade focaccia.  I tend to shy away from focaccia (this from a bread-lover) because it is so often cardboard-y.  Not at da Flora.  This was fresh and homemade and delicious.  

We shared speck-wrapped asparagus and pork with tuna sauce.  Both were fabulous.   Then my husband got a pasta dish with garlic and onions and anchovies.  I don't like anchovies, so I didn't have any, but he was in heaven.  I got the petrale, grilled perfectly, on a delicious bed of zucchini patty.  We had planned on going for a walk after dinner and stopping at an Italian bakery for dessert, but the food was so good that we decided to stay and split the pistachio cake on meyer lemon creme fraiche.  Oh my god - it was easily on my top ten ever dessert list.

I looked at some of the bad reviews before I went.  Good lord - who the hell pans a restaurant because he asks for a table at peak time and just wants a glass of wine, then gets pissy because they won't make his wife a cappuchino.  Go somewhere else.  Leave Da Flora for food-lovers.  Get out of my way - I'm going back as often as I can.
author: Linda S.

description:
I have NEVER left a place before my meal has come...NEVER except for here.  It all started when they didn't want to seat us because we were looking a bit casual...and it just went down hill from there.  We asked to split a meal because we wanted to get an appetizer and a dessert as well as a bottle of wine and wanted to have room for it all.  We were scoffed at and then snickered at as the waitress walked away and within seconds of coming back and informed us they were out of the special anyways.  After choosing again, she informed us they were out of that as well.  After asking what they did have, and having a short reply...we placed an order.  

However, the longer we sat there, the more agitated we became.  We informed the waitress we didn't want our meals after all and left.  I was humiliated by the treatment. 

I can't rate the food but the service the worst I have experienced.
author: Karie V.

description:
Flora & Mary-Beth make this place. It did take me nearly two years of regular dining to figure things out, but it has been entirely worthwhile.

If you live in San Francisco dine here. Make a reservation, and let Flora guide you.

If you are from out of town and have simply wandered too far North on Columbus, then turn around and head back for the tourist spots where you belong. Otherwise you will likely irritate Flora or Mary-Beth so, please, don't mess with the ladies. They won't like you and you won't like them.

{I do enjoy their haughty dismissal of tourists, it is a secret pleasure of the place}
author: C M c.

description: Very nice ambiance! Went in for a wine and a starter only (place was empty) - menu was difficult to read for a foreigner and the waitress (apparently the owner) was not nice at all when we didn't order a main dish at the start.. Didn't like that at all and felt pretty uncomfortable. Would come back though for a full dinner!
author: Daniel H.

description:
Let me start by letting you know that I don't really enjoy eating super rich foods.  So for all those that get a little queasy thinking about a plate of alfredo, read on; all others, ignore this review.  

So I didn't barf, but I have felt like sheit ever since last night's dinner.  To start, my boy and I split the gnocchi.  Which was very tasty and probably the best made gnocchi I have had in the city.  Unfortunately, it was covered in and a thick cream sauce that had super fatty pieces of bacon in it.  I had a couple of half bites... You know when you stop mid-chew because you know you have just sunk your teeth into something that it is just pure fat... cringe.  I am gagging just thinking about it. 

Next I had the lamb shank, which was excellent.  The meat was really flavorful and fell right off the bone.  But again, there were big chunks of fat in it.  And because the lighting was so dim in the restaurant, I couldn't determine what I was eating.  So yes, I had some phenomenal bites of delicious lamb, but  the next bite tended to be an entire mouthful of grody fat.  (cringe)  ...My eyes are tearing at the thought...  I must note that one of my dining companions did not seem to notice at all and, to my horror, ate the whole thing (gag). So maybe everyone loves eating hunks of fat and I am simply the oddball... It wouldn't be the first time.

The desserts (I don't remember exactly what they were as they were never read - they were just told to us) were hit and miss.  There was a cookie platter, which is passable, and a phenomenal fruit-like cake with a sour creamish topping.  As my boyfriend said, next time we should just get the whole cake and forgo dinner.  The cake was really good.

All in all, if there was no fat on my plate I would have given Da Flora 4 stars, but since it tainted almost every bite I took, I am going with 2 stars.  Also, the service was really slow, I needed to practically beg for an entree recommendation, and it is 1:30 the following day and I still feel yucky.

And no, I will not be back.
author: Hayley W.

description:
I wanted to give a one star but I can't because it wasn't the worst meal I've ever had.  What an absolute dissapointment.

First, Flora looked very descheveled in a dirty sweatpants type outfit. Not a great first impression.

I wanted to order the lamb but when I asked for it, she said it wouldn't be ready for another hour. Excuse me, but if you have lamb on the menu, you should put the lamb in the oven so that it's ready for when guests arrive! 

 I ordered the lettuce and watermelon radish salad and the dressing seemed like nothing more than olive oil.  Being an avid cook, I understand the power of a dressing of nothing more than a good quality olive oil, but this dressing completely fell flat. For $9, I already felt ripped off.  Then, I had the orichette pasta with rapini.  It wasn't orichiette at all! It was fusilli and completely devoid of any flavor.  I had to keep adding salt ...just to taste it! I can't believe I paid $19 for a pasta that I could have thrown together for $3 at home. 

All in all, if you're tastes are used to the Olive Garden, feel free to go to Da Flora.  I can't believe how expensive that was for something so basic.
author: Mia B.

description:
SF Food Inspection Score: 96

man this is a tough one to call...

it really comes down between the food (5 stars) and the service (2 stars). so i think a solid 3 is a nice median. though there is nice ambiance, it is really bad for groups and more suited for the neighborhood folks that frequent the joint. more explanation to follow...

the food: UH MAZING! sweet potato gnocchi, anchovie linguine, lamb, veggies, and the dessert is out of this world! if you come here for anything, it's the pistachio lemon cake...roar!

the service (owner): BOO. the owner was just unpleasant, had some major 'tude, and seemed like she hated the fact we were there. (we were a group of 7). and the prices are just ridiculous. with one bottle of wine, the bill was $70 per person...ouch. but the actual servers were very helpful and friendly!

allow me to digress....

we found this place on bay area check please and were stoked to check it out. but da flora was not stoked to have us there. i understand that it's more of a friends/social gathering/date night kind of place. but come on, show us some respect Flora...my boyfriend's parents took us there to celebrate a graduation and they shelled out probably $500 (!!!) for their family to be scolded for misunderstanding your "hand written" menu (it's scribbled with poor cursive writing and photo-copied on construction paper). And don't scoff when i ask if the bathroom is available as if i'm a child. 

there was a moment when we couldn't establish what to get for dessert. we were trying to figure it out and she just went off and basically told us to hurry up. it came to a point where i had to tell her to just give us another minute because we can't be rushed. she stomped off and had her servers take care of it. i felt it was quite unprofesh of her.

this woman made it seem like this place was her house and we were crashing her dinner party....she knew everyone else in the place because they were probably well-paying regulars. it just solidified my feelings about some NB places being elitist and classist. 

ok, well that's it. i will go back for the food but if she gives me any poop, well, i really just can't go there anymore. which will be fine for her and for me.

you get one more shot Flora! not that she would give a hoot, but i don't want to be disappointed again...
author: Kristina C.

description:
Just went to this restaurant after seeing it on "Check Please, Bay Area".  I'm still feeling kind of mixed about it.

The food was really really good.  Focaccia is incredible...I could have eaten that all night.  We got the fig appetizer.  It was okay, but nothing that screamed OMIGOD like the gnocchi apparently does to other yelpers.

For dinner, I got the Transylvania chicken dish, and my husband got the Monk fish dish.  Both were very good.  For dessert, we got the lemon pistachio cake...it was just okay.

I have a couple issues with this place.

1) way too expensive.  Our final bill was $75 plus tax, and that was for one appetizer, two meals, one dessert and water.  That is extreme, especially considering that we couldn't take any doggie bags home.  The portions are reasonable for a meal, but I feel like if I am paying $25 for a meal, I should be able to have enough to take home.

2) servers.  They were both really nice, but honestly, if I am forking over $90 for a meal, I don't want to see sweats and Tevas on my server!  Call me crazy...

Overall...I am glad I tried it, but I can't say that I'll return.
author: Jen M.

description:
Second Review:  ( 2 stars)
I originally gave this place 4 stars and would always recommend this place to friends and out of town guests!  Now - it's down to a 2.  Why?  I got food poisoning one night after eating there.  I don't lower my rating because I got sick - that happens at any restaurant.  I lower my rating because I called to let them know I got food poisoning and NEVER received a call back.  I would expect a place like this to call their customers back and at least apologize.  That's all I was looking for.  So, it get a two in my book and not sure I need to go back. 


First Review: (4 stars)
Don't expect any attention when you walk into this place, unless you have a reservation and don't take it personally if the owners don't give you the time of day.  You need to work up your reputation at this place.  If you walk in off the street, you're considered 'riffraff' which is probably what happened with us.  My mom had been there before and warned me that if we walk in there without reservations, it's not going to be welcomed.  Once we got over the fact that we didn't get any attention for the first 15 minutes of being seated, the owners started warming up and I could see how great this place is!  

The ambiance is spectacular, food is wonderful (the menu is constantly changing (--feels like you're in Italy with the handwritten menu with about 10 items) and wine selection is top notch.  These two ladies know their wine and let them pick something out for you once you decide what you're ordering!  The sea scallops are delicious and orecchiette with broccoli rabe is delicious!  

The only thing holding me back from having this a 5 star is the 'standoff-ish' attitude you get as a new comer.
author: Katie T.

description:
Was on a date with my BF and looking for a place to eat in which we haven't tried yet-thus we stumbled upon Da Flora. The place looked really cute so we decided to try it. As soon as we walked in, the waiter tried to sit us near the window and my BF requested to sit in the back corner in which the waiter denied us the seating (for no given reason) so we just sat where he wanted to originally sit us. 

That should've been a sign to leave, but we still gave it the benefit of the doubt. Overall, the food was decent, however-service was horrible. 

Besides the seating, we never were even served bread which I'm sure came with the meal since all the other tables were sever bread before and after us.

And then when we were ready for our check, no one paid attention to us, so my BF politely said, "excuse me ma'am" to the waitress (possibly the owner) and she rudely responded with, "I'll be right there." Didn't even look at us! And never came back to help us and instead had the waiter come over. RUDE!

Would not recommend to anyone because if you are paying 100 bucks for dinner, service should be considered unless food was that good, and it was only decent.
author: Laura B.

description:
I LOVE this place, but there are a few things you must understand before coming here.

1.  This is VERY important, so listen up.  DO NOT come here without a reso or think you can walk in when you see empty tables.  They are very Italian about their service and if they don't feel like taking any more tables that night (no matter what time it is) you are SOL my friend.

2.  Get the gnocchi...its to die for

3.  Let them select the wine for you.  Try something new - they have an extensive list of wines you have probably never heard of, so venture out of your comfort zone people!

4.  The lamb can feed 3 people, so beware because you WILL have leftovers.  Of course, there is nothing worng with that in my opinion.

5.  Flora (dark brown hair) is the wine expert...and Fauna (or at least that's what I call her) is the foodie.  You will get better results if you direct your questions accordingly.

I think this place is amazing and a must try for anyone!  Hand written menus, romantic, quaint, and so uniquely Italian that you may just miss it if you are not paying attention.

Bring cash....they prefer it!
author: Megan H.

description:
This is the best meal I have eaten in my entire life! Mary Beth the pastry chef/server is genius with her desserts, bread and personality. Flora is incredibly informed and sweet in her own way.
Seriously, this is the best restaurant I can recall eating at.

Just perfect!

Thank you Da Flora. :-)
author: J R.

description:
My date could not have picked a more romantical venue for Vday. Adorable, cozy restaurant. Red walls, maroon draperies, and candlelit. The restaurant is almost hidden from the outside world which adds to its appeal. 

The waiters must have been in a more loving mood (in comparison to past reviews) since I found them to be pretty friendly. They were helpful in the wine selection and were prompt on the bread delivery. Ahhhhhh the BREAD-amazing! Salty, fried foccacia bread, nothing like it. Kind of like a salty donut which just melted in your mouth. I was beyond pleased already. 

The salads, however, were nothing to write home about. I ordered a crab salad on cabbage and the crab had a "fresh can/linoleum" taste to it. And the combo over the bitter cabbage and raddicio did not mesh well together. My date's salad resembled that of leaves with some chunky unidentifiable cheese. He wasn't too happy either. At this point we were a little taken back already and were curious as to how the pasta dishes would pan out. I was pleased with my pea raviolis with shrimp and would definitely recommend it. An odd combination that was surprisingly tasty. My date's gnocchi was eh......he/we have definitely had better and it didn't live up to its hype. 

The main entree: braised short ribs. Pre-tty good. Served with polenta and broccoli. I did notice a few dollops of sour cream which was both unneccessay and unpleasant. The ribs were seasoned enough as is. 

Overall a solid 3 stars. Based on the pre-set menu I dont know if we would come rushing back. But Da-Flora does deserve recognition for its ambiance.
author: Heather S.

description:
We were going to see the Beach Blanket Babylon show, and we looked for a good Italian Restaurant to enjoy before the show.  We chose this place, and I still have mixed feelings...

We made reservations for the same evening, and were told we could eat there as long as the table was vacated before 8:15pm.  Fair enough...we waited until the last minute...

When we got there, though, I was disappointed to see the menu...it had very few items on it, and the hand-written descriptions were both difficult to read and difficult to understand.  When we ordered, they seemed very to take issue with the fact that we were not getting wine (sorry...wine before a show would result in me sleeping through the show...) , and the server (owner, I think...) made it a point to tell us that we were not ordering enough food.  

The food itself...well, my wife had the sweet potato thing and she liked it...and we augmented it with a ceaser salad that was completely uninspired.  I can make a better ceaser at a salad bar at Sizzler.  

I had a pasta dish with a lamb ragu.  Although it was for the most part okay, I thought that the very soft cooked carrots that were part of the dish did NOT compliment it in the slightest, and gave the dish a taste that reminded me of beef stew.  If the pasta had not been home made and quite good, the dish would have been a disaster.

I think that the best thing about the meal was the bread.  

The last thing that disappointed us was the note on the menu that said something to the effect of they prefer to accept only cash.  Come on now, it's 2009...when I'm traveling I pay with credit card for EVERYTHING, as I don't like to carry cash.

Anyway, I've had better meals, I've had worse.  Overall, I'm sure that most people enjoy eating here.
author: Robert N.

description: Venetian Duck Liver in Porcini sauce and Sweet Potato Gnocchi are to die for. Who needs a trip to Venice when you can have it at a little corner Venetian Osteria Da Flora in North Beach, SF. Grazie Da Flora !!!
author: scott v.

description:
UPDATE (dinner #2 at Da Flora)10/28: 

I finally tried the sweet potato gnocchi  - quite tasty; but I felt the rigatoni  with butternut squash was the big winner of the night. I went with a new group of people last night, and they all absolutely loved the food and ambiance. It's just a homerun kind of place... unless you have some freak in your party who doesn't eat carbs (BORING). 

To say that parking in No. Beach is a Second Bardo nightmare, which might keep you from ever getting around to try this restaurant, would be an understatement - last night we discovered that there is a public parking lot right across the street from Da Flora - BONUS! 

I also appreciate that the servers consistently suggest delicious and moderately-priced wine pairings (instead of trying to shame you into ordering one of the most expensive bottles).

Original review 9/24: 

Truly the tastiest Italian food I've ever had and such a CUTE, cozy, romantic, unique restaurant. The staff is wonderful and personable, too.

Small criticisms/warnings: 
You have to get there early, or there's a good chance they will have run out of a good chunk of the menu - including the gnocchi, which rumor has it is their most fantastic dish (and I didn't get to try!! Oh darn, now I have to go back). Also, they only use unpasteurized/raw milk cheeses  (according to our waitress), so if you're pregnant you have to steer clear of the cheese (and as far as I'm concerned food is just a vehicle for cheese, so that was a bit of a bummer for me).

Overall a fantastic package, though - I hope to go back again and again.
author: rachel m.

description:
I keep meaning to go back to Da Flora for dinner again, since I had only been once almost a year ago. So last night we finally went back for round two. Wow, it was fantastic! Even better than I remembered it.

I came upon Da Flora through "Check Please Bay Area" and have been gastronomically uplifted. This is a wonderful restaurant and it's understandable that most of the people there are regulars.

On our first time we had Da Flora's fantastic signature dish of sweet potato gnocchi with a bacon sherry creme sauce- oh my god, it's beyond heavenly, that dish is fucking orgasmic. We also had penne amatriciana with house-cured pork cheek, which was also very good. Then we had some kind of fish dish, maybe skate - I just don't remember all these months later.

Flora also helped us pick out a bottle of great Italian red wine, something that she really excells at. They ONLY serve Italian wines so I needed some help choosing.

The second time we went (last night) to start we had the sweet potato gnocchi and the porchetta tonnato (carpacio-thin sliced pork loin with a tuna fish/mayonnaise sauce) which was also fantastic - an interesting combination that really works. After eating both of these appetizers we decided that just the one gnocchi wasn't enough, so we ordered a second (I've never ordered a second round of any dish in any restaurant before!!) Each bite was pure bliss. And the focaccia was perfect for soaking up ALL the delectable gnocchi cream sauce

For entrees we had a fantastically flavorfull risotto with grape tomatoes and an unsatisfying monkfish with lentils, chanterelle mushrooms and arugula, which was a little bland. I would have prefered some kind of meat: lamb, pork or beef; unfortunately, the menu only had a Hungarian paprika chicken dish, the monkfish and 5 pasta dishes. The monkfish didn't fulfill us (we should have ordered the chicken), but the other dishes went beyond expectation.

For dessert we had the apple crisp with vanilla ice cream. Funny thing, a restaurant patron came up to us and told us this dessert was not to be missed. So, we ordered his recommendation and the apple crisp was certainly very good, but it wasn't all that. My partner, who was facing the dining room, said that she noticed that everyone else was eating the apple crisp too. Only a warm apple crisp would have been noteworthy. So, I suspect they were out of the warm out-of-the-oven apple crisps and we got a cold lackluster one. However, I'm not going to deduct any stars because 3 of the dishes were so utterly to-die-for and I will be going back more often.

We brought a bottle of 2005 Rochioli Pinot Noir, which was OUTSTANDING and paid the $20.00 corkage fee. I felt bad not inviting Flora to pick us out a bottle of Italian wine from her huge selection, but I was dying to drink this pinot.

I love this restaurant and want to become a regular patron too. Thank you Da Flora restaurant for 2 outstanding meals.
author: Yvette K.

description:
We walked up (or is it dow) to Da Flora on a saturday night with no reservations. We were lucky there was a 1-hour window to the next reservation. The hostess/owner was kind enough to seat us. Note that I did not see a restaurant name since apparently some drunk preppy kid (owners words) had taken a bat to her window. That's north beach for you. I thank my lucky stars that I did a double peek into their window and was enticed by their cozy space. 

This place is great!! I hate hate hate North beach on a saturday night but this time I had no choice as my mom wanted to see San Francisco. The tourist trap that is north beach is normally such a pain, but now that I've discovered Da Flora, I am feeling much better about the trek. 

First off, its small. +1 Secondly, the menus are also small and handwritten! +1 The bathroom is so quaint and cute! And the wine selection is very good. 

We shared a blood orange salad that was dressed in a wonderful vinagrette, topped with thinly shaved red onions and green and black olives. Served with nicely salted bread to mop up the vinagrette. 

My mom had the buttersquash risotto with swiss chard. It was perfectly  cooked and the chard was a nice contrast to the creamy risotto. I had the lamb bolognese sugo on handmade parpadelle. It was divine!!! We both had a glass of wine made from a grape whose name I will mess up .. la grime it sounded like. I will have to google it. It had a lovely deep color with a very smooth finish. Found it .. its called lagrein! 

The bill came up to $77 excluding tip. It was a little pricey but well worth it. Next time I will make reservations and bring the hubby!
author: Pica L.

description:
The gnocchi appetizer is the best in the city, bar none. The wine selection is entirely small Italian wineries, huge, and they know all the wines (and are perfectly happy to recommend the perfect one for your meal). Wonderfully romantic, and very small - get a reservation! A reputation for brusqueness, but if you're nice to them, they'll be nice to you. My favorite SF Italian.
Read my full review at: http://sibilous.blogspot.com/2004/08/da-flora.html
author: Don H.

description: Perfect for a romantic date. The food is excellent. If the food is less than excellent, management makes amends. I recommend the sweet potato gnocchi appetizer and the fish of the day as the entree.
author: Carrie H.

description:
Had a very pleasant dinner here the other nt.  Reasonable prices and cozy, small place.  Warm red decor and nice red wines.  Thought the appetizers were all good but the main courses left something to be desired.  The thin-sliced pork with tuna was probably my favorite.  The gnocchi is deservedly famous and tastes like you are biting into a little love pillow.

Service in my experience was fine if somewhat absent.  Can understand how people have been turned off by Flora, and think the cash only is annoying, but think this place overall is a gem.
author: Brad C.

description:
Oh geez.  Da Flora.  Where do I start?

5 of us needed a last minute reservation away from downtown because Macworld had taken over the city, with friends were in town from Australia for this ungodly convention that clogs up our fair city.  We fortunately got in!

We started with the white bean bruscetta, baked asparagus with some kind of sour dough breadcrumb, and the gnocchi.  Holy smokes.  I am dreaming of that gnocchi right now.  It's the fluffiest, lightest, sweet potatoed piece of heaven you can imagine.  Pieces of thick cut bacon, crispy sage and a light cream sauce.  That Jen in the kitchen sure knows what she's doing, it's incredible.  All of it was. It was one of those situations where you wish there were not 5 people.  I wanted to order another round of appetizers!

Two had the pork chop and 3 the ravioli.  It was all amazing.   The handwritten menu is cute and fun and writing this review  I am tempted to go back in tonight with just one rather than five and share a few more things (but I won't).  I will, however...hit it up soon.  We shared creme brulee, some kind of chocolate cake and a berry cobbler thing with vanilla ice cream.  All astounding.

I had been here once before with my parents and it was awesome.  I made an observation to them that I'd bet we could get our palms read or get tarot carded here;  the atmosphere is dark and romantic but not so much that unromantic liaison's like one with your parents or 4 friends seem weird or out of place.  Da Flora is extremely comfortable, amazing service and incredible food.  

What more do you want?
author: annie s.

description:
Just had a fantastic meal here with a dear friend.

Must-haves: 
- butternut squash gnocchi with smoked bacon in a light creme sauce was the best gnocchi I've ever imagined
- lamb shank was tender, smoky, and flavorful
author: Chris M.

description:
The staff are all friendly and down to earth, and you can tell they love what they do. We enjoyed our blissfully delicious gnocchi appetizer so much that we ordered a second one. The menu is very unusual-- not your red sauce, veal picatta kind of North Beach joint. LOVED this place---- even the bathroom is charming!

UPDATE: Made a long overdue return last night and the place is even better than I remember! I can't fathom the staff being anything but smiling, friendly and real...so when I hear about negative experiences here, I just don't get it. I think the key is to make reservations instead of trying for a walk-in. But dining here should be a planned event, not an afterthought. LOVE IT.
author: Maureen G.

description:
Simply the best restaurant in the city. 

Great for a romantic dinner or night out with friends. These ladies know what is up! Everything is personal, from the hand-written menu to food. Been here a few times and always leaving with a smile and a full belly. It is always hard to make a choice cause everything sounds so yummy. Flora has an amazing selection of wine and knows what she is talking about. Always welcome their recommendations and never think twice. Perfect for a lovely long dinner with a real intimate setting, forget you are in a restaurant. 

Few things to know, reservations are a must! 
They do accept credit cards but prefer cash. 
Please leave your children at home, this is a grown up only zone!!
Be ready for a dinning experience. 

Crave the gnocchi all the time!! Every dish is thought through,  always seasoned perfectly and presented simplistically graceful. Recommend everyone get something different so you can taste how heavenly everything is. The menu changes with the seasons and shows great knowledge of food.     

Can't say enough great things about this place, truly one of best hidden gems in the city. Flora and Mary-Beth welcome you with open arms as if you were their only guests for the evening. They work hard and put love in everything they make.
author: Danny B.

description:
Five of us went to Da Flora last night for a birthday dinner and had a great time. The food was delicious we all had something different and shared. The staff was attentive but also allowed us to sit there for 2 hours talking and laughing and didn't try to rush us out. My husband said the short rib was the best he ever had and he's a real goody.
I'd highly recommend this restaurant and we will definitely be going back.
author: vicki g.

description:
The reality is, this place deserves 5 stars. The food is probably the best in the city as far as Italian goes. The only reason I gave it 4 stars is because at times the service can be slow. BUT if you are going for the food, then 5 stars it is, if you are going for a complete dining out experience, you may not be a fan. Now me, I L~O~V~E food and this is amazing.

The gnocchi is like nothing I've ever eaten. anyone trying Da Flora out for the first time will miss out if they do not order gnocchi. 

Now as for the service, personally, I really like it. But I'm more of a hole in the wall type of person, so it's right up my alley. They are there to cook up a GREAT meal. I don't mind a wait for a meal that is prepared after we order. Great place for some romance, it's quiet, small, and intimate. 

Enjoy!
author: Teresa J.

description: I came here with the BF after a long happy hour at Salt House.  The restaurant's wall is painted in red and the ambiance was cozy and romantic. It was not busy on a Friday night at 8:45. We had a reservation and was immediately seated at a small table by the window. The menus were hand-written and included 7-8 item selection each for primi and secondi.  They had awesome focaccia bread that were drizzled in olive oil. We ordered their popular sweet potato gnocchi for appetizer, Penne with tomato saurce and bacon, duck liver for entree. Everything was wonderful. The rich taste definitely hit the spot after the drinking. It was a very nice evening.
author: Lucy W.

description: Wonderful food and great atmosphere.   Wine selections are unique and service splendid.  I love this place !!!!
author: Anne V.

description:
Cozy local place with tasty food.

I'm generally against having to make reservations to eat at a local joint (used to live in NYC, DC and Chicago and only made reservations for birthday , anniversary and graduation dinners) but this place is worth asking someone else to get a table.  It's also good to go with someone who's already been there (which I did).

I would love to eat here once a week on my way home from work (I would just eat and drink whatever they gave me) but it's too busy to just drop in and definitely more a place for couples.
author: Songbae L.

description:
ok, i admit.... flora was to' up from the flo' up....
she was sweaty & couldn't be bothered by our excitement.

but this was precious & amazing.

best dinner i've had in a while.

::sweet potato gnocchi, pork tenderloin, risotto, house made lemon icecream, pistachio lemon cake::

the menu was handwritten = perfection
and the wine selection! among the 7 or 8 tables, wine was in every nook and cranny.

i will take every visitor here to this north beach tiny hidden gem.
author: tiff f.

description:
I read the yelp reviews and despite the remarks on bad service I decided that the praise about the food from the yay-sayers was too hard to ignore.

The service is not as bad as described. The owner does seem to come off like she is burdened by life but she wasn't rude.  The rest of the staff was friendly and attentive to refilling glasses and checking back on whether you enjoyed the food or needed anything else.

It's a small place. You need to have a reservation if you expect to get a table, especially on weekends.

The foccacia is really excellent - it's airy and lighter instead of dense and heavy and he olive oil that is drizzled on top is quite delicate.

The sweet potato gnocchi was tasty enough but not to die for. You wouldn't want more than the appetizer size portion because otherwise expect it to sit heavy. It's best shared with someone along with the Caesar salad which is very authentic tasting

I was surprised that there were not more proteins on the menu. There was a fish dish but otherwise everything else was a pasta. I had the parpadelle which was served that night with a hearty lamb ragu sauce. It was excellent. The best dish all night. My friend had the sole which was cooked just right, very moist.

For dessert we tried the chocolate shortbread sandwiches with the filling of mascarpone cheese and honey. While very good, the cookies were too thin and I would have preferred a bigger bang of intense chocolate. We also tried the pistashio-lemon-almond cake - the lemon was the predominant flavor, you couldn't taste any almond or pistashio really. It's a stickier cake, maybe it is made with almond paste. The cake grows on you the more you eat it. But overall I think I would go elsewhere for dessert.

I would go back to De Flora and hopefully catch a night where the menu includes the dishes that other reviewers loved but for now there are other great restaurants in North Beach that I'll try first.
author: Harold P.

description:
I had this halibut last night that almost brought me to tears it was so good. I felt like such a butterball I scarfed it down,but it was so tasty I had to devour it .

Ambiance is great, I would go on a date here if I went on dates. When my vow of celibacy is over, I will go here for said dates. It will be rad.

try the appetizer with the oranges, you will go bonkers.
author: Lauren V.

description:
Don't get me wrong, the food was yummy. I ate it up lickety split with gusto. And all my fellow diners were suddenly silent during the service of the main course letting me know that they were quite pleased.

Still, having spent some time in Venice I was really looking for more seafood. Cicchetti, polenta with mystery fishies (I think they're octopi), john dory - these are the dishes I've been missing. 

Most of the dishes were hearty and meaty. All fab but not the Venetian experience I was hoping for. Still delicious food, so I have to give them the stars they deserve. But if you're looking for the full Venetian experience, wait for the cheap flights in the Spring.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Bad customer service. Just wine & no other drinks beside mineral water. Sloppy handwritten menu. Limited food! No variety. If you like wine and drink wine then you will probably like it :-)
author: Cecilia B.

description:
Awesome place, My boys over at Tom's Beautiful hair took me over there knowing I am a cook and they would always talk about it while they were styling my golden lox.

The space is warm and inviting, perfect date spot if you can get a table. The owner/hostess/somelier/waitress and all around bad-ass was totally cool, especially since Tom and Tom were regulars.
