The wine list is all Italian to the best of my knowledge and I'm lost in Italy when it comes to wines, only knowing a few but...the whites and reds recommended were just great. I told her I'm a full bodied big dark dried fruit with a long finish and low tannin kind of guy with my reds and she hit the mark. I prefer my whites in the same depth but would be fresh stone fruit as opposed to the red, big fan of Riesling characteristics but also of a little malo-lactic fermentation so that buttery finish...again hit the mark.

Food...I started with a Artichoke stuffed with bread crumbs/garlic/parsley and olives, nice and thin lemon aoli surrounded it. The only criticism I had were that a couple of the outer fibrous leaves weren't removed. But other than that I loved it and finished before I realized like a jackass I didn't give everyone a taste. They all started with fava bean puree on toast with I believe some lemon extra virgin sprinkled on top. Nice and fresh, an itty bitty touch of garlic but bright and a nice little "summer's here" starter.

I had Red wine braised duck livers which were awesome, mama had the sweet potato gniochi which lived up to the hype. Perfect little pillows in a light cream sauce, very good and I can make some gniochi lemme tell YOU. Tom had the mushroom risotto  which was perfectly done, a lot of the time people will finish with to much Parmesan but this had just enough. I forgot what the other Tom got but I think I remember a braised red meat of some type on polenta, Tom ate it so fast didn't get a bite but he and others vouched for it.

We shared the strawberry shortcake and these little stuffed macaroons. I'm some what of a strawberry conesuer and since it was so early in the season for them it was obvious from the flavor and the fact that they had the tell tail sheen on them from having sugar sprinkled. The short cake was perfect and the cookies were great.

A great spot, can't wait to go back and see how the consistence is, but I have a feeling any date I take here will be happy.
author: Scott S.

description:
Ambiance: 5 stars. Friendly owner and attentive, friendly wait staff: 5 stars. Quality of food: 4 stars.  Wine selection: 10 stars. They have SOOO much good wine.  And they love to tell you about.  

Cost of wine: -2stars.  We spent 3 times what we wanted. They wine is expensive.  Very expensive.... However, it was good. And I would do it over again. Just not very often...

Excellent date place.  Highly recommend and out of the way of the tourists. Go there, and bring a romantic date. Just be prepared to spend a little money on the wine...
author: Dapper D.

description:
After an awsone dinner at this spot in North Beach, not much I can add to other yelps, but I can concur with a few things so that readers have a better idea of what they can expect:

The gnocci was the best we have ever had, like pillows... just perfect.  No fat on the bacon, which was the tastiest and smokiest bacon I've ever had.

The osso bucco was amazingly tasty but as others have said, there is way too much fat for $26. Probably 20 percent of the dish was fat.  Detracts from the thing overall, but I'd still order it again, that's how good it was.

Butterleaf salad was great.  Raw garlic in a salad dressing is questionable, so garlic-phobes might not like it.  But to us the dressing was perfect.

The staff was attentive and friendly, granting us repeated changes to our reservation.  Our waitress, not one of the two owners, was accomodating, never rushed us, was responsive without being hyper, was there when we needed her, and left us alone when that's what we wanted.  The owners even treated my girlfriend and I (who were celebrating a milestone) to a $5 table-side poloroid, taken by a neighborhood eccentric who was welcomed by them with open arms.  (Note: if you do not want a friendly enough interuption to your dining experience, pass on the solicitation... quickly.)

Apple crisp with vanilla ice cream was great as well.. the crisp was the perfect light counterpart to the heavy-ness of the ice cream.

Lastly, unlike what some other yelpers have said, they do in fact take Visa and MC, they just prefer cash.

Overall a near perfect experience.  Highly recommended.
author: Aaron W.

description:
Very cute charming place with tasty food. I am not sure why all the complaints about the service because we thought it was wonderful and very attentive. We were even given a few wine recommendations based on what we liked and ordered. 

I had an eggplant pasta dish which I remember being really good...We didn't get the gnocchi which is what this place is most well-known for, but that didn't seem to matter much. It was one of our favorite dinner spots on our trip-- and I would definitely come again...
author: Daniela A.

description:
Lovely intimate Italian restaurant that feels removed from the bustle of touristy North Beach. I had the lamb osso bucco, and it was out of this world good. The gnocchi were divine as well, but the osso bucco stole the show.

Our waitress was friendly and professional, offering good wine suggestions.

I'd definitely go back.
author: Colin B.

description:
My Favorite the food is fantastic.  Wine selection is excellent.  Decor wonderful.  (The most romantic bathroom in the city, bar none). 

What ever you do, don't answer your cell phone, and try not to look like you are from the burbs.  

I went with my Sister, Bro in Law and  a buddy of theirs once.  We were dressed pretty casually.  We looked at the wine list and tried to order a primativo.  The owner looked us over and said, "I think you should have the Chianti."  (The chianti was pretty good).  

I have been back several times and it has been great every time.
author: John M.

description:
If you walk up/down Columbus Street in North Beach, you will undoubtedly pass a ton of bustling, crowded Italian restaurants.  Of course most of them are average at best and many even have long wait times.  Da Flora has the best food I've had in that area by far and it's very quiet and cozy relative to other places in the area.

I can't remember everything we ate, but every dish was excellent.  The gnocchi was phenomenal and there was a pork loin that was absolutely mouthwatering and tender.  Also, the bread they serve before your meal is out of this world.  I would go back for the bread alone.  

It was a pretty slow day when I was there and the owner/staff/and maybe a friend or two were sitting at a nearbye table talking about food.  You could just tell that they were all very into food and it was reflected in their ingredients and the flavors you tasted.  They don't dress up or put on a lot of pretense servicewise, but that isn't really an issue for me.  I know it may bother some when you're out and paying fancy restaurant prices.  But they were nice and gave good answers to menu questions and such.  It was a bit pricey, but definitely worth it in my opinion.  My parents are visiting in August and I plan to take them here.
author: Zach J.

description: I like places that have their own personality.  Da Flora is completely unique in the Bay Area.  If you want Chevy's "Fun" or Olive Garden "Variety" go somewhere else.  Bottom line...Da Flora food quality, and wine selection has always been excellent.  I have been dining off and on at Da Flora for over 12-15 years.  If you want high quality venetian food with a great wine selection, beautiful setting and interesting personalities to serve you eat here....
author: mark g.

description:
Such a delightful treat! Da Flora returns to the boutique-y, family-owned, food and wine focus to Italian food to North Beach. Flora, herself, served my table and showed off her vast knowledge of Italian wine (breaking it down by region and making sure it paired with the food we ordered). The food was delicious! I recommend the heirloom tomato with arugula pesto, salt cod crostini, proscuitto wrapped figs, eggplant rigatoni, and squid ink risotto.

YUM!!!
author: Becca P.

description:
Warm, charming room, red to the point of looking like a whorehouse in a cowboy picture. Obese, sweaty-browed waitress (co-owner, I gather) accommodated us five on a Saturday night, though we had no reservations. That was nice. They were half full, but expecting a big reserved party.  
She was truthful about the menu. The portions weren't too big, she advised us, despite every entree being $22 and up, and light on meat options (!?). When asked for her recommendations, she said that everything on the menu was "an acquired taste," which sounded at once puzzling and condescending. The one dish she praised glowingly was the Hungarian one. In an Italian restaurant.
The house red was $10--high even for San Francisco.
The capper was that she wouldn't send a ticket for just the appetizers to the kitchen. At that, my  friend, a restaurateur, folded his menu and said this wasn't working for him and we all left.
After a long wait, we were accommodated at a busy, tasty little place up the street, L'Osteria, and were reminded what good, friendly service is.
author: John H.

description: Went to dinner here with a few friends several weeks ago and was blown away. The Sweet Potatoe Gnocchi was perfect, delicate, fluffy, and really rich, but in a good way.  I had the Spicy Sausage Penne and really enjoyed everything about it from the perfectly cooked penne to the spicy sausage that had a slow burn that made you just want to eat more. I cleaned my plate faster then anyone else at the table and had to sit there kind of sheepishly as my more refined and mannered friends finished their dinners. Da Flora is a fabulous place that I would absolutely frequent if I lived close.
author: Alli B.

description:
5 star for decor
4 stars for food
2 stars for fear-ridden visit
1 star for possibly - turned and overall lame $45 wine

Following 1) colorful recommendation by a very good friend, 2) glowing review by a 10 year Northbeach Residence (as well as my friend/co-worker), and 3) many weeks of anticipation, i finally made reservation to this little restaurant. In my party: three close pals, one of whom, T, lived in Rome till the age of 29. 

I was told ahead of time that one of the waitresses is the sweetest lady ever, while the other one is...for lack of better words, Shrek. "How would I be able to tell them apart?" I asked naively; "Oh you'll know." okay. so off we go.

As usual i was late, my buddy was already seated at a perfectly sized table - actually, the decor was pleasant. Red walls, wooden tables and chairs, fairly comfy setting. it wasn't cramped, and was pleasantly lit. The overall vibe was just quaint.

So, as my friend had predicted, i had no trouble spotting Shrek. She floated about the joint with the authority and grace of Jabba the Hut, and looked as lovely as Valerie, wife of Miracle Max.  As I tiptoed around her to join my friend, i felt her dirty look washing over me. I smiled at her sweetly and sat down, keeping my voice level strictly inside. My co-worker friend happened to be sitting next table with her husband, so i went by and said hellos. At one point I uttered the phrase "Yelp Review" and was prompted shuushed by my regularly visiting friends - apparently, that's the express train ticket to Shrek's shitlist-shire. I tipped toed back to my table, and soon my italian friend joined us. 

As suggested by fellow helpful Yelpers, my group decided to defer our wine selection to Lady Shrek. We also told LS that our friend is italian, and they started to chat table side (totally charming, if i weren't so awash in fear, i'd enjoyed listening, instead i just smiled politely while looking like a total tard.)  Shrek seemed truly delighted to practice her italian with my Roma friend. Turns out that she's hungarian, and had lived near venice for a long time and had worked at a kitchen there. Hence, when she came to the states, she opened up an italian joint. Oh, and she suggested the $45/bottle wine. surprise. We ordered 1 plate of "legendary sweet potato gnocci" to share to share among the 4 of us. This displeased Lady of the Hut; but since my italian friend was there, she was still rather gracious about our grave error, childing us for potentially inconveniencing her, "I will just have to go tell the chef to make this again when you guys reorder!" Drama Mia! 

Our wine came. Me, being a wine simpleton/novice, could only tell that the wine is somewhat lame, and especially in relation to the price. Later on a huddle revealed that the "cellar-y" wine perhaps has "turned." Again, no idea what this means - so maybe just be extra careful about committing to the wine based on the price. The wine list is extensive, Jabba the Shrek boasted about 200 types supposedly. but that could also just be marketing babble.  It's hard to tell since the woman seem to lack the "warmth and sincerity" gene.

No complaints about the food. The sweet potato gnocchi was indeed delicious. (Mrs Miracle Max will tell you that the menu is designed so that each guest can consume a primi and a second, that is true only if you're training for your next competitive eating contest. My table of four shared a plate of the gnocchi for app, and each ordered an entree, and I had some left overs and was ssstttuuufffed; find you, my appetite is not to be trifled with usually, so this is not the appetite of a salad-eating gal here.) For the record, I had the Tagliatalle with Ridicchio - and even with the fearful service, I'm tempted to go back again (but i know better, esp after this self-indulgent review). 

To sum up my feelings - visiting Da Flora is not unlike having dinner at your bipolar spinster aunt's house, (the one that is afflicted with the hairy chin.) The food may be delicious,  but you're just a little too scared to breathe to enjoy it.  Plus, that supposedly pricey wine is just kind of iffy.
author: Lynn T.

description:
Da Flora is one of my favorite unheralded gems in the city. As others have mentioned, the sweet potato gnocchi with pancetta sherry cream sauce is worth going for alone. I also fondly remember a height-of-spring appetizer with fresh favas, olive oil, and insanely fresh and creamy ricotta cheese. Amazing.

I've been going for almost 10 years and the quality is still as high as it ever was. Highly recommended as a romantic date location. It's small, so not suited for any group larger than 4 really.
author: Celeste S.

description: Flora's is fabulous! It's my favorite restaurant. From the deep red walls, to the quirky, funky, vintage art, the sweet potato gnocchi and the flowing prosecco, you will feel as if you've stepped into a magical corner off a Venetian canal. I even love how un-obsequious Flora herself and her wait staff are. They are real people who are not catering to rude tourists and other riff-raff. Flora's dedication to quality shows up down to the detail in her beautiful, hand written, ever changing menus. Everything she serves is fresh, authentic and exquisite!
author: Severin C.

description: This is my very favorite place!  They have the best food and the absolute best Italian wines in all of SF.  Whatever you do, just let Flora pick the wine out for you! Jen, [the chef] is amazing.  She can cook!  The pork W/celery root & artichoke friter is delicious.  The sweet potato gnocchi is mouth watering.
author: Lynnet S.

description:
Perfectly cooked scallops, hard-to-find Barberas, and oh-so-light-and-fluffy sweet potato gnocchi.  They have more wines than they list on their wine menu, so be sure to talk to the sommelier slash owner.  And yes, the menu is handwritten, which for some reason is completely charming to me. 

North Beach dining with no tourists and no overly peppy servers is the best.
author: Abby and Brent s.

description:
Had dinner here the other night and found it delightful. Food was average for North Beach, service was adequate. 

On a side note: Dan "Quail's" last name is actually spelled Quayle. Looks like spelling errors can happen to anyone, Laura D.
author: Natalie K.

description: Everything you have read is true, the service is not the greatest. However if you actually get in to eat the food is so good it makes up for whatever else is lacking. The "viking" sisters who run the place are great in a "soup nazi" kind of way. If your a tourist forget it you will never get in.  Fantastic food done right. A gem in north beach. my only suggestion, if at first you don't get in keep trying it is way worth it. Just don't ask any stupid questions.
author: Jerry M.

description:
Eating at Da Flora is a challenge, make no mistake.  Bring the right attitude and you will be rewarded.  The owners are passionate about their food and their wine.  They are very knowledgeable about what goes with what and if you trust in their choices, nine times out of ten you will not be sorry.

Flora is a formidable lady.  But if she likes you, you are golden.  She is a whizz at picking the right wine for your table, mood and food.  the food is delightful and the wine sumptuous.  

Flora seems to flit from table to table chatting to what appears to be a lot of regulars and friends who come calling.  This is a little gem and you will be richly rewarded if you realise this is not your run of the mill Italian eatery.
author: maggie s.

description: We are long-time and now part-time sidents of North Beach and know da Flora well. We returned this evening and had one of the best meals obtainable in San Francisco. No foam filled spoons, no agar beads, just incredibly delicious food, exquisitly prepared.  This is a restaurant that serves truly amazing dishes from start to finish.  This North Beach gem is as good or better than ever with a superb wine list and amazing deserts to compliment the first class kitchen.   Flora, Mary Beth, and Jen are to be congratulated for serving up  a great dinner in a warm and welcoming setting.  We shall be back as soon as possible.
author: Jeff L.

description:
Really, one of my favorite Italian restaurants in the city.  Intimate, quiet, romantic and all the food is made with love.

The whole team at Flora do an amazing job.  

I love their focaccia, gnocchi, and while I would love to go on about the delicious meal we had, all I can say is that on every occasion that I go there, every meal is memorable and delicious. 

I highly recommend trying this restaurant if you havbe not already and you will be a believer as well.



HINT:  Make a reservation.
author: Eli B.

description:
We were delighted to get same day reservations on a weekend, perhaps because it was a holiday weekend.  Service was prompt.  Two of our three servers were pleasant.  Flora seemed to be having a bad hair day and made it clear that our questions were absurd and serving us was a task.
The food.  It was solid and fresh, but did not live up to the accolades we've witnessed.  The 'fresh and solid but not outstanding' descriptor applied to most of the dishes, including starters of asparagus & egg salad, Caesar salad, arugula salad and a main dish of pork loin.  The much anticipated sweet potato gnocchi were heavy and pasty - as if we were eating something different from what others write so glowingly.  Ditto for the pistachio cake dessert - nice but not a stand-out.
It's good to be able to rave about one item on our table - the bread.  It was crisp on the outside, chewy on the inside, and generously decorated with olive oil and crunchy salt.
Glad we tried it.  Unlikely to come back.
author: Anne J.

description: This restaurant is incredible.  Period.  The sweet potato gnocchis are the best i have ever had.
author: Nicole T.

description: What a find! Had a truly unique and amazing meal -- delicious all the way around. The food was simply superb - Venetian Italian with Hungarian influences. The decor felt sumptuous and elegant yet cozy enough to drop in for a week night meal. Fantastic Italian wine list. The staff was very friendly and informative. I will put this one on my "regular" list.
author: Sally V.

description: I can't comment on the food but certainly on the service (or the lack there of).  We had reservations on Saturday night at 8pm and were there a few minutes before 8.  The hostess told us that "Some people came late" so she didn't have a table for us - which is fine (totally understandable). When we asked how long it might be she said "I'm not a sorceress but it shouldn't be too long" and she asked us to wait outside.  35 minutes later we were still standing outside in the cold.  I can understand that occasionally people arrive late but if they are so late that it ends-up impacting others that have a reservation (and who arrive on time) then the restaurant shouldn't seat them. So after a 40+ minute wait we bailed on the place.  I don't think we'll ever come back.  Burn me once, shame on you... Burn me twice... shame on me!
author: Jim S.

description:
Da Flora: Poor Customer Service

On Saturday, March 8th, my partner and I had reservations at Da Flora, located at 701 Columbus Avenue in San Francisco's North Beach neighborhood. We planned on celebrating his birthday there. I had told them it was for his birthday when I made the reservation, and they made a note of it. We made the reservations a month in advance.

To confirm our reservation, I called Da Flora on Friday, March 7th. Reaching their voicemail system, I heard that they were only accepting reservations from women in honor of International Women's Day. I left a voicemail asking that they call me and tell me what was happening with our reservation. They returned the phone call to cancel the reservation.

Let me say that I fully support their decision to honor women on International Women's Day and respect their decision to have a women's only night. After all, my partner and I learned about their restaurant on Check Please! Bay Area, where they highlighted that Da Flora is owned by two women, somewhat of a rarity in the restaurant world, and we wanted to support a women-owned business and have his birthday celebration. Plus, all three panelists on Check Please! Bay Area raved about the food, the ambiance, and the customer service.

The problems were two-fold. First, the woman who returned my call said they tried to call me. However, I never had a missed 415-area-code phone call without a voicemail, nor did I receive a voicemail. I believe that I would have remembered my partner's birthday plans being canceled. I want to give them the benefit of the doubt, but it sounds like an excuse for not letting us know that our reservations weren't being honored.

What would have happened if I didn't call to confirm? Would we have been turned away at the last minute on Saturday?

The second problem - and I may be most perturbed about this - she offered no follow-up offer of service. It would have been nice if she offered us a table on Sunday, perhaps with a free dessert, glasses of bubbly, just something. She offered tacit platitudes and nothing else. Even after I reminded her that it was for my partner's birthday and asked her if there was anything that she could do, she did nothing.

My partner and I select restaurants to try based on recommendations, and customer service for special occasions is of paramount importance to us. They knew that we made the reservation for his birthday, and they did not care. 

At the last minute, Da Flora canceled our reservations for my partner's birthday. They barely offered an apology. They did not offer any follow-up service. If we had shown up without confirming the reservation, we would have been turned away without notice. That is what I call poor customer service - to say the least. 

A copy of this letter has been posted with or emailed to Yelp, Trip Advisor, and Michael Bauer.
author: Justin J.

description: I am very happy to finally found a place in North Beach that is not a tourist trap and is made for locals. The atmosphere is just great, with a very old feeling that really brings me back to my vacation in Venice. The food is great. I had a delicious bruschetta as appetizer and pasta with sausage cooked just right. Great wines and "interesting" service: Flora is a character. Oh, I almost forget : you have to try the chocolate cookies with mascarpone cheese for dessert!
author: Tracy N.

description: A Strange and Unpleasant experience (except for the fact that I was with my Sweetheart).  The staff - plain weird and rude.  The first woman rolled her eyes when my gf asked politely for some water.  They up-sold some over-priced wine which was totally mediocre. The waitress scoffed when we inquired about the least expensive wine on the menu, which was still expensive by the way.  Why are you serving it if it's so worthless?  More of a reflection on your establishment than our taste. Another North Beach rip-off, thinly disguised as "real".  I love hanging out on the north side of town, but where can we eat without feeling jacked?
author: emmanuelle a.

description:
With due respect to all the heavy promotion from the SF Chron and all the hype from john q public:  the emporer has no clothes!


Overall, the kitchen did an adequate job, although we felt the pappardelle (served with fresh fava beans) was overcooked.  Yes, Mary Beth's focaccia was near perfection.  We are in the wine trade, so it was puzzling not to find more current vintages on the brief, one-page listing of Italian white wines.  First we learned from our server (who boldly announced herself as the "wine buyer"), who we later realized was the owner Flora, that the wine we requested was unavailable because it was not chilled down.  After we agreed to wait while the wine was properly chilled, we were then informed that this wine was no longer available.  After listening to Flora try to convince us that a red wine would pair with our food (which it wouldn't), we finally convinced her to tell us about some other Italian white wines available, but not listed on the wine list.  We selected a 2004 Greco di Tufo from Campania that proved to be excellent!  However, when we asked for the wine to be rested on ice to keep it slightly chilled, we were informed that the restaurant did not have any ice!!!???  
 
It was a rainy Tuesday evening about 8 o'clock, and the restaurant was less than half-full.  Throughout the rest of our dining experience, we felt like we were a complete afterthought, although we were the only ones seated in the middle of the room.  This included waiting for my empty wine glass to be replenished (the wine bottle was not left on the table), while Flora sat at a table 3 feet behind me clipping newsprint articles about the restaurant for a scrapbook.  Flora never did make the effort; we finally had to flag down her compatriot Mary Beth for assistance.
 
The final insult was getting someone to bring the check/take our credit card so we could close out our bill.  By the way, the menu reads that cash is preferred.  (Upon reading this notice when we were seated, we made a point in letting Flora know that we only had enough cash for a taxi, and would a credit card be okay?  We were assured it would not be a problem.)  So, we waited, and waited, and waited, while Mary Beth stood with her back to our table visiting with acquaintances at a table along the wall.  Flora continued clipping.  Finally, my wife stood up and put on her coat with great drama for attention, but no one noticed.  After my wife politely interrupted Mary Beth, our AMEX card was whisked away, only to be returned a minute later with the explanation that this was not an accepted card.  We kind of figured it wouldn't be, but were startled that the card had to actually be "swiped" before anyone woke up to pay attention.
 
Perhaps we should have picked up the subtle clues the moment we walked in- BAM!  You're in the middle of the restaurant (nothing to create a soft entry- for you or the diners seated near the icy blast of cold as you enter from the street)... the tired, kitchy decor (NOT romantic, as others would leave you to believe; peeling floor tiles are not attractive, nor are dusty dingy artifacts strewn about)...  the slovenly attire of personnel (yeah, we know it's North Beach, we know it's cold, we'd like you to be comfortable, but please dress in clean, professional garb and put on a happy face)...  and the grossest moment of the evening, when Flora placed a dirty (I mean not just fingerprints- this thing never ever saw a dishwasher!) wine glass in front of the wife and had to be asked (nicely I might add!) "May I have a different wine glass?"
author: Eric S.

description: Wow! Never treated so rudely at a restaurant in my life!! Brought my parents here when they came in from out of town, asked if there was a full bar and the fun started there... The rather large, incredibly rude hostess, then snapped that only wine was available - working on making a decision we we're basically bum rushed out of the place. My mother, "beside herself", felt obligated to vacate the restaurant. Needless to say, we didn't try the food and I've never been so mortified in my life. Unless you're into WWF do not try this place, it'll just piss you off and make you look like an idiot for suggesting it. Never again!
author: Blake W.

description: I had a wonderful meal and experience at Da Flora.  I live right up the street from this tiny restaurant, and had been wanted to try it for some time before the opportunity arose.  My boyfriend took me for our anniversary and we were not disappointed.  We had the gnocchi to start, and it was amazing!  it's hard to say, but I think it was my favorite part of the meal.  Our entrees and dessert were delicious as well.  I particularly appreciated that when we asked for a wine recommendation to go with what we had ordered, she didn't instinctively point to the highest price bottle on the menu.
author: Nathalee S.

description: Best Italian restaurant in SF! God bless the Hungarian lesbians of SF that make eating out so tasty.
author: John P.

description:
We stumbled in on this place on a Friday night, with no reservation, but they had a table and seated us. The interior is very cosy and quaint.  The menu was a bit hard to read since it was xerox copies of handwritten menu items, but that was part of the adventure. I ordered the pork tenderloin, but they said that was replaced by some uninteresting chicken dish. So I went with my second choice, which was the scallops. Wow, that was good. Not just because it was rich (which it was), but because it was an excellent paring of tastes that I wasn't expecting would work out -- the sauce was mashed sweet peas! but it was really good. It reminded me of a meal I had in northern Italy, in the Piedmont area, that was the best meal I can remember. Of course, we only at 1 course in this situation and we didn't have time to spend all night at the restaurant, but the flavors of the food were spot on.

The total cost of the meal for 3 people (just secondi's and the cheapest bottle of Barbera wine) came out to $150, so this isn't cheap, but I think it was worth it.

I would have given this place 5 stars if it weren't for the extremely frumpy, overweight, unattractive staff dressed in black sweat suits. Obviously, they are foodies foremost; everything else is not important.
author: Mark L.

description: The earth moved my first time at Da Flora! It was a balmy Indian Summer night, and just as I was about to take a bite of cheese filled squash blossoms, SF experienced a minor temblor. Food here is perfection.  Service is attentive, straightforward, no nonsense. I'm still daydreaming about my most recent meal-- the gnocchi, butter lettuce salad with pecans and pomegranate seeds, broiled duck liver with polenta. The focaccia! Sigh. Have dessert with a cup of real coffee. (No decaf!) The Big One could happen at any moment.
author: Cynthia C.

description: The food is fantastic, but it's not worth the disrespectful service and attitude. I've been to my share of upscale restaurants and I'm hardly demanding, but I honestly left this place thinking the owner and staff were racist.
author: Bihn K.

description: A co-worker recommended this restaurant a few years back and ever since then I've been a huge fan. Da Flora is a small quirky place on the periphery of North Beach. Getting in can be a bit challenging if don't make a reservation. Flora the owner and chef with her partner Mary Beth create exquisite dishes of the Venetian region. One highlight that isn't always one the menu is the Sweet Potato gnocchi with pancetta and cream sauce. You'll want to fill up a swimming pool with this stuff and slowly wade through it gulping mouthfuls as you swim. Oh yeah and you'll use Mary Beth's focaccia as a floatation devices. Everything on the menu is fresh and authentic, the wine list in extensive, but if you want he good stuff you'll need to ask Flora. Oh so nice.
author: Matthew R.

description: A friend and I walked in without a reservation and they were very rude, as if it was completely presumptuous of us to try to eat there.  We stood there for a while before anyone even acknowledged us and then were basically told to leave.  I didn't appreciate the attitude and won't be back just out of principle, even if the food is good.
author: Rebecca S.

description: Heard great things about this place and decided to try it! After parking and walked over and found the place... We were asked to leave since we didn't have reservation even at 6:00 pm!  The place was not packed and they just started service, they just flat out told us to leave and did even attempt to help us or say something nice... I dod't believe at this kind of economy, restaurant turn away customers and don't care about it
author: Addison C.

description: Outstanding Venetian cuisine. We ate at Panisse the following afternoon, and yet the memories of Da Flora could not be diminished!! Duck livers and gnocchi were AWESOME and fabulous wine parings suggested by our hostess. Lovely bohemian-chic atmosphere crowned by Millie the transient who takes photos of tables with her polariod. (At the end of the night she gets her own seat in the back and a bowl of pasta) Prices were what we expected coming from NYC.
author: Brian H.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. The food is amazing and the wine list is well-curated. In my experience, the service has always been good, but not amazing. My favorite dishes are the sweet potato gnocci and the orecchetti with sausage, but I have never had a bad thing.
author: Hilary W.

description: We went to this restaurant based on yelp reviews and were definitely not disappointed. The staff was very knowledgeable about food / wine pairings. The Gnocchi, as promised, was really a treat; I loved the combination with bacon. And my main dish, the rigatoni, was fantastic. I wish I knew the recipe so i could make it myself every week. This is our new favorite Italian restaurant in the city
author: Eric B.

description: I wish Yelp let me make a list of places I haven't yet been, but really want to try.  Alas, it does not (yet), so I am rating a place for a list I am making which I haven't even yet been to, but I hear it's great, so I am giving it the benefit of the doubt and giving this place high marks.  I can' t wait to try it.
author: Todd R.

description: Absolutely delicious! From the olive oil soaked bread to the gnocchi appetizer to the homemade ice cream - unbelievable. Eat there...now.
author: Hilary R.

description: So good! Great wine list, and staff is helpful with pairing. The gnocchi was delish and the before dinner bread was super tasty. Yes, Flora is a bit disheveled but it doesn't stop her from serving a great meal.
author: Yes P.

description: Our favorite place to eat! Heavenly food in an intimate setting where you feel like a special guest every time.   Wish there were more places like this around.  Great wine list and cozy environment.  We've been going to this special place for over 11 years and have never been disappointed.  We have never had rude service as others have mentioned in their reviews.  The food is so good that many of my other favorite places pale in comparison.
author: Melanie W.

description: Probably the best authentic Italian restaurant in North Beach. The food is unbelievably good. Not inexpensive - prepare to spend around $50 per person but so worth it for a special night out. The decor and vibe lends itself to a romantic dinner experience. The sweet potato gnocchi is to die for.
author: Kathleen D.

description: Fabulous food, variable service. Please try to go on a night that is not a weekend. The sweet potato gnocci appetizer is the best gnocci that I have ever had. They bake everything in house - the foccacia is superb, the desserts are heavenly. The bread/dessert chef is one of the waitresses and the Flora, the chef and owner of the other waitress, which is why the service is so slow. Go, relax, spend all night. Have the cheese plate and dessert. Decide what to order and let Flora choose the wine. She knows her wines and they are wonderful. This place is pricey, but worth it. Cash preferred.
author: Vena V.

description: A block and a half from our house.  Our go to for a special date.  Love the food and wine.  Probably one of my favorite selections of Italian wines in the City.  Consistently produce delicious creative dishes in one of the most charming spaces around...  Go Flora:)
author: R M.

description:
I have to say this place was worth every star...and so much more. Lets start at the beginning:
Eclectic vibe and warm ambiance makes you forget that you are in a restaurant and feel more like in a funky dining room at a friends house...plus they are so nice! I walked in on crutches and they were all over me with warmth and kindness.
Because of the vicodin, I could not splurge on my usual bottle of wine (which covered the piano and back bar tempting everything in me) but I did indulge in the house red and it was a really nice surprise!
Now, the food...oh mama mia!!! Let me put it this way, I took my parents here and if my mom is not complaining you know somebody did something right! The sweet potato gnocchi is out of this world...and I hate sweet potato!! The foccacia was like something straight out of my Nonna's kitchen and the main course was to die for. The menu is interesting and adventuresome, changing daily...a refreshing change for NB. Moving right along...
LETS TALK DESSERT!!!! OMG, I could have died right here and been a happy girl. I had a plum and bluberries tart with vanilla ice cream that was one of the best things I have ever tasted!
Reservations are a must...as is not skipping a single course or leaving a single bite behind...

PS Bring cash...they dont take plastic...
author: Jess W.

description:
We were walking down the street and I glanced in the window... Mme. D and I walked on a few more steps and I just had to go back and check out the menu. It looked wonderful so we decided to see if we could get a table. I tapped on the door and asked (it was 5:20). Someone checked with Flora. Yes!

I ordered the butter lettuce salad. A gorgeous looking salad - and it was was excellent. We also had some focaccio. It was the best I've ever had. Slightly crunchy with olive oil and sea salt.

Next was a meyer lemon risotto with fava beans. A few fried green onions on the top. I don't like lemon in foods but their chef has a marvellously subtle touch and it complemented the risotto perfectly. Mme. had the gnocci which she liked. 

For desert a Sicilian cake with pistachios, etc. Marvellous.

They have an extensive selection of Italian wines, particularly reds. Most of them are from Italy - from all over Italy including many areas with which we had no prior experience. Ask Flora for advice.

Unlike some others we found the staff to be friendly and helpful.
author: Tony M.

description:
My first experience with this restaurant came one day as I was walking past with my girlfriend.  In front of us a young girl was walking with her father--she turned to him and commented "Daddy, this looks like a will-you-marry-me place."  It is small, romantic, and quirkily decorated.  I love it.

Flora (the proprietor) is bad ass.  Don't f*** with her.  Regulars know what I'm talking about.

The food is fantastic.  The only dish I'm not enthusiastic about is the orrechietti.  The chef tends to be heavy-handed with the garlic on this one particular dish.  The gnocchi and chicken livers are both excellent.

Flora knows her wine so, unless you are extremely knowledgeable about the bottles on her list, ask for and heed her advice.  Her wine list is extensive and eclectic.  The vast majority of the time she succeeds in helping me select an excellent bottle of wine.  On the rare occasions when the bottle is not something I'm thrilled with it still turns out to be an educational experience.  Her wine is NOT cheap but it is worth it.

Amen -- DR
author: daily r.

description: My favorite place in one of my favorite neighborhoods -- fabulous food and hospitality in a great setting. The Sweet Potato Gnocchi is not to be missed!
author: Amy A.

description:
Really good food.  You could come here just for the focaccia that comes with the meal, but I wouldn't stop there even if I could.  All of the appetizers entres and dessert  we've tried there have been delicious.  
The drawbacks: Flora gets snooty if you don't take her word as gospel and spend the money.  The site is more hole-in-the-wall then elegant... dispite the velvet curtains.  And there are too many pasta dishes and not enough meat dishes.  Typical for Italian, I know, but if you are really hungry for some protein, save going to Da Flora for another night.
Still, everything tastes so yummy, you gotta keep things in perspective.
author: Katie R.

description: Where are the people who are in the restaurant business for the love of food & wine? They're at Da Flora, rustling up authentic Italian dishes behind the dusty curtain of an old world-looking dining room. Sweet potato gnocchi with pancetta and a luscious cream sauce ... Toasty foccacia bread with just the right touch of salt ... Homemade pasta, fresh and cooked to perfection ... Just the right wine, selected for you & your meal ... Candlelight, candlelight, candlelight. If you don't finish wanting to rush home and make out with your dinner partner, there's something wrong with you.
author: Katie B.

description:
Living in North Beach, I've tried most of the Italian restaurants on Columbus at least once.  I've had my eye on Da Flora for quite some time, but its opening hours are a bit irregular, so we just finally got there this weekend.  It was open, and we were walking by, so we thought we'd see if they had room.

The food here was definitely the best Italian food in North Beach.  The other restaurants aren't anything significantly different from a chain restaurant like Del Pomodoro.  But this one...Fresh ingredients, unique recipes.  And the bread!  Fabulous.  If I had to pick a word, I'd pick exquisite.

The service was great.  We even went with our six year old son, and they treated him like royalty.  They even made him a small dish of tomato sauce when the pasta he ordered was too anchovy-ish.  

If you want something in North Beach worth the extra money, this is it.  There is one other restaurant with great food (Trattoria Contadina), but Da Flora just has that extra *something* that makes it the best.
author: Susan B.

description: This restaurant is a breath of fresh air. The service is attentive but unhurried. It's like having a good friend cook for you--one you've known for so long that they don't need to fawn over you any more. The food is seriously good. Like roll-your-eyes-and-moan good. Bring someone who will trade bites with you! The prices are reasonable for the high quality.  The room is romantic, with dark-red walls and lots of candles, and on a warm evening, the doors stand open, providing a view of the park and the passersby.
author: Jamey M.

description: When in Rome~ Something about this place brings smiles to my face. My girlfriend from out of town received a recommendation to come here. "An absolute must?" Well, yes, we found that to be 100% true. After ear to ear smiles from the decor, we continued to be enthused from  the wine recommendation to the fabulous gnocchi. Grab a bottle, enjoy the entree's, and prepare to go to Heaven.
author: Peter N.

description: My Italian friend highly recommended this place.  The sweet potato gnocchi is incredible - you can taste the doughy gnocchi that was clearly freshly prepared and boiled to perfection.  I had a pomegranate and walnut vinaigrette salad which was good, but it sounded better on the menu.  For an entree, the lobster risotto was calling my name... but I was a little disappointed with the lack of richness.  While my food was good, it was not great.  Part of my issue was that my expectations were through the roof, but I think that if you go in expecting decent Italian, you'll be pleasantly satisfied.
author: Jared F.

description:
Bottom Line: Overpriced.

The full story:  We managed to get last-minute reservations here on a Friday night.  Yay for being able to accommodate us.  But honestly, I am not sure why it was so full when I left.  The food was tasty, the gnocchi (like every has already said) are AMAZING, but dude, my penne was so not worth $20.  And their house red was also not worth $42.  Two Buck Chuck is equally tasty and palatable.  I was aghast that between appetizers, entrees, and wine, our meal ended up in the neighborhood of $60/person.  This was, at most, at $30/person kind of place.  I've had way better, fresher, and more unique Italian food for much less money, and I didn't have to go all the way to the outskirts of North Beach to get it.  I think the only return customers they have there are those kinds of people who firmly believe that you can't get a decent meal for less than $50, and just refuse to eat at restaurants that serve better but oh no, CHEAPER food.  Definitely will not intentionally be back anytime soon - at least not until they are willing to serve me more than six gnocchi at a time.
author: Becky N.

description:
We ate here last Saturday night and apparently got lucky to get a table. Some people changed their reservations one minute before we walked in. I had never even noticed this place before but it's quite popular. Dozens of people were turned away at the door.

I am lactose intolerant so my review may be useless to you. 

The host/waitress at this place is very unpleasant and not fun at all to deal with. However, the food runner is super nice and pleasant and makes sure you've got enough of the delicious, but terribly greasy, focaccia. 

What we ordered:
Small Plates:
- Carpaccio- It had creme fraiche so I couldn't eat it, but everyone else liked it.
- Hot Coppa- I had this one and thought it was nothing special.
- Gnocchi (sweet potato?)- Everyone loved it. I couldn't eat it.

Entree:
Penne Arrabiata with Calabrese Sausages- The pasta tasted like Barilla and was unimpressive. The sauasage and sauce were tasty, but not spicy at all.

Overall, it was better than the other Italian places I've tried in North Beach (Mona Lisa (meh), Stinking Rose (vom), and Cinque Terra (double vom), but that's not saying much at all.

If someone knows a good Italian place in the city that's lactose intolerant friendly (I can have sheep and goat cheese, just no cow), let me know.
author: Saikat P.

description: This is a quirky little gem in the heart of North Beach. The burgundy walls give it a funky sort of 60's feel. Get the Sweet Potato gnocchi with pancetta and cream sauce. They are the lightest I've ever had, like little pillows that melt in your mouth. Lemon Almond Pistachio cake with house made creme fraiche made this a carb overload with the Focaccia , but well worth it. We did not have the service issues that others have written about, but I did notice that they had a very relaxed attitude that may not be to everyone's liking. If you are comfortable in NYC restaurants, you will be right at home here.
author: Arlene C.

description: little pearl in the madness of non authentic Italian food of North Beach.  I recommend their creamy gnocchi (to die for, note very small portion). Orecchiette with rape, like the real authentic thing you would get in Ialy. Go for the pistachio dessert you will still dream about that for days and days...wine is expensive but they have a great selection.
author: Biemme B.

description: As good as it gets is right. This place was amazing, the best food I have had in a while that was not a regular for me. If you go you HAVE to get the sweet potato gnocchi it was delicious, divine, wonderful - I wish I could have gotten a full plate of it, we practically licked the plate clean but we had the help of cleaning it with the AMAZING focaccia, they had to give us four plates of it because we loved it so much! This restaurant is in my top ten of all time, we got lucky in getting a table from a someone that canceled, so you have to make a reservation and it is well worth it!
author: Jenel G.

description: Back to Da Flora again. Chef Jen McMahon has hit the mark once more. Pappardelle with duck and radicchio: fall down great pasta! Ask owner Flora about the best Barbera to go with it.  Jeez-us!
author: Lars M.

description: Totally reminds me of Italy!  Intimate, handwritten menus, not touristy.  You must try their sweet potato gnocchi in a sherry cream sauce with smoked bacon.  We actually had a Hungarian paprika chicken stew with polenta -  interesting flavors & rich, it was good.
author: D L.

description:
I agree with the other reviewers that the gnocchi appetizer is exceptional, as is Flora's ceasar salad.  And Flora recommended a great wine pairing.  But sad to report neither was enough to make up for my entree - ordered a "lobster" mushroom pasta and it was completely overcooked and pretty flavorless. 

I've been here several times and usually like it, so hopefully our next visit will add a star....
author: Jane M.

description: Hands-down my favorite restaurant in San Francisco, and a place I've loved since first going there some 14 years ago.  As some of the reviews show, Da Flora is not for everyone.  You won't find chicken parm on the menu, they don't like patrons who want to grab a bit and run, and they aren't particularly charitable to people who complain that a Venetian restaurant should have more fish (it should -- but the type of fish available from the Pacific just won't cut it for Adriatic cuisine).   But if you want excellent, interesting food, and a staff and owners who will, over time, let you earn the right to be treated like family, this is the place.
author: Frank C.

description:
hands down my favorite italian restaurant in the city! i stumbled upon this place by accident one night while killing time during some bad bimbos opening bands. we didn't have a reservation, but i think years later, it is impossible to get in here without one. and rightly so.

da flora is SO cozy! the interior is tiny, dark and non-offensively italian looking. the menus are handwritten and change daily, and are just filled with the most  unique seasonal italian dishes.

flora is always there, and is this totally awesome larger woman who is not your typical hostess. she knows everything about where each ingredient comes from and ask her for her wine suggestions. perfect. 
. 
the food is so incredible! each dish is subtle, flavorful and brilliantly crafted. every taste lingers in your mouth for just seconds, and you are left wanting more. go here with time to sit, drink, eat and savor each bite. 

you WON'T be dissappointed!

p.s.  this is what real focaccia should taste like.
author: Mara G.

description: I would have given this place 4 stars but for the fact that we were virtually ignored from the minute we sat down.  Ok, the food was pretty darn superb but I like to be treated well while I'm eating superb food.  There was literally no extra conversation from the wait staff--beyond asking us what we wanted to order--and no follow-up at all.  The only reason people are eating in there is because the food is really tasty.  Flora and her partner need makeovers.  At a minimum, they need to wear clean clothes and at least TRY to act like they give a shit as to whether or not you will return.  It's too bad.  I really loved the food.
author: Maria A.

description:
Da Flora is my heart.  It is our favorite restaurant in the city and has been for almost ten years.  Flora is outstanding.  Her menus, which are created daily and are handwritten, include wonderful food.  Please try the gnocchi as a starter.  Her foccacia (served as bread before the meal) is the only foccacia I have had in North Beach that actually tastes like the foccacia in Italy.  For your meal, if you're not sure, ask Flora - she will give you her honest opinions (unlike many restaurants who want you to just buy the most expensive dish).  For wine, figure out what you would like to order as your meal, then ask Flora for a recommendation - again, you will receive an honest, thought-out recommendation, a perfect wine to compliment your meal, and it is usually more reasonably priced than the wine you had picked out.  The restaurant is beautiful, charming, and intimate and has the perfect ambiance.  

Tip:  make a reservation, always - even if you believe it is not a busy night.  It is a courtesy.  Flora and her staff really prefer that and it is understandable, as they are a very small restaurant who plan the menu out every day.  For the folks that are saying, "You can't get a table" and "They hate tourists," that is so untrue.  They do not appreciate people walking in off of the street, people talking on their cell phones, rude people, belligerent people, or people asking for fettucine alfredo.  As long as you make a reservation, and use some basic manners, of course they will serve you.
author: Katherine H.

description: After being told that the wait would be at least 45 minutes at Tommaso's we ventured over to Columbus to see if there might be something without the dreaded line out the door. Da Flora appeared to be a cozy and relaxing restaurant so we figured we'd give it a try. Compared to many of the other restaurants along the way, Flora's is very quiet, and in fact you can even have a conversation without losing your voice (good luck with this at many other North Beach eateries). The waitress was kind enough to seat us immediately, even though we did not have a reservation. The menu was a bit hard to decipher, as it was hand written in not the easiest to understand script. However, the sweet potato gnocchi with parmesean and sage stood out as something I absolutely must try, since it has been years since my old Swiss Italian friend spent a half a day mass producing these heavenly sweet and savory dumplings back when I was a poor graduate student and couldn't afford to eat more than ramen noodles. I also ordered the salad of the day- watercress with cherries, sweet and creamy gorgonzola, and almonds and an accompanying drink of prosecco. While we waited for our food, we snacked on the foccacia- rather plain tasting- but probably authentic Italian (I remember in Italy, the bread was bland). Once the gnocchi arrived I was in complete heaven- these drops of bliss were served with a light and creamy sauce, and garnished with fried sage. Ordinarily the dish would come with bacon, but since I am not a bacon fan, opted to omit this component. While the portion was appetizer size, I am glad that I did not scale up the portion, as our waitress had suggested, as the dumplings were very rich and satisfying. The salad was a great compliment, and the prosecco made the entire experience bubbly and magical.
author: Kate A.

description: I tried to have dinner tonight at Da Flora, but did not expect to be treated with contempt. I arrived on at 715 pm and the restaurant was empty. The only table that was offered was one next to the door. When I asked if I could have another table away from the door, I was told that "all the tables were reserved". What a bunch of nonsense and not the way to make a potentially good customer feel welcome. (I walked by an hour later and the restaurant had some diners but it was not by any means full. ) I am not a tourist and in fact live in the neighborhood, but I would not consider giving this restaurant business when there are so many other welcoming venues with delicious food and good service in San Francisco.
author: K Z.

description: I tend to find restaurants that I like in North Beach and then quickly forget them. I don't want to forget the name of this one so I'm writing this review to prevent me from doing so.  The best scallops I've ever eaten - and an amazing apple crisp - the atmosphere is really romantic, and it just felt very authentically Italian.  I would go again.
author: Sara J.

description: Terrific food and even better ambiance. Small, red, cozy, quiet, great view and very romantic - a little slice of Venice in North Beach. The perfect cure for all those other hoity-toity joints with too many tables crushed together amid the conversation killing din. At Da Flora you can actually enjoy a conversation with your meal, Hurrah! I notice some reviews kvetch about the owner being a little snarky at times but she's really quite funny, unique and interesting, and she's great when you need a recommendation from the large wine list. I think she's a kick. For an intimate romantic dinner, Da Flora is one of my favorite unpretentious spots. Did I mention the great food?
author: Clay W.

description: we ate here last friday on a recommendation from a friend.  the food was excellent!  the owner, flora, is a "strange bird" indeed, as my friend had warned me.  upon greeting us at the door, she asked us if we would be done and able to leave by 8pm because the place would get packed by then and she wanted to make sure she had tables ready!  at first, we were put off and tempted to leave but we stuck around and ended up having a wonderful meal.  my hubby started with the gnocchi and finished with the rigatoni.  i had the beef carpaccio which was delightful and a huge portion, and finished with the papardella with fava beans and caramelized onions.  we finished with a slice of lemon chiffon cake with fresh strawberries and whipped cream.   their foccaccia is amazing and definitely non-vegetarian (*probably made with lard).  and her wine selection was really impressive.   a fabulous find!
author: Cyn B.

description: I actually really like this place - it's quirky and red inside but a real NB gem. You must eat the sweet potato gnochhi - it's the kind of food you dream about. The people who work there are also a little quirky - and so is some of the decor (although they just updated it) but the food is fantastic and the wine is spot on. I think this place is a great value and has that little neighborhood feeling that you miss with other places in NB
author: Christie W.

description: great food and ambiance and helpful wait staff. Its size is intimate and more on the romantic side. The food was pleasantly surprising and my guests loved it.
author: gary a.

description: I think the real debate on this restaurant is about the service. There is no question that the food is undeniably delicious and the wine list is vast and affordable.  And the ambiance is absolutely phenomenal...very warm and elegant in an off the wall kind of way.  The service however, is undoubtedly indifferent, at best. At times, it is downright rude.  And let me say that I have worked in restaurants for the majority of my life, so think I have realistic expectations for what service in a restaurant should and should not include.  I did notice that the wait staff is very chatty and friendly with certain people so I think if you are a regular and they know you,  they do take very good care of you....which could account for the varying degrees of disagreement about the service here.  Ultimately, the food is worth the visit. Set your expectations low on the service aspect of things and you will likely walk away delighted.   But do make a reservation.
author: Lulu L.

description: Tiny, warm and romantic with Italian opera playing in the background, very European feel, friendly, knowledgeable service, excellent food, not cheap but reasonable prices for what you're getting.
author: M B.

description: WOW!  I love this place!  I thought I was going to have to write about the so-called horrible service but the service was fine.  Flora, the owner, is a little rough around the edges.  But she was very helpful in suggesting a great wine for us and completely redeemed herself.  The rest of the wait-staff was very polite and helpful.  What we should be talking about is the food.  The food here borders on perfection.  The focaccia is sublime.  The gnocchi were little heavenly pillows of goodness in a perfectly balanced pancetta cream sauce (I'm sorry mom!).  The squid ink risotto was as good as I've ever had.  I'm not saying I've had a lot of squid ink risotto.  It's obviously not an everyday dish.  But, growing up Italian, I have had a lot of risotto.   This was as good or better than any I've had.  Enough said.   For dessert I chose the plum blueberry crisp with vanilla ice cream.  It was another display of baking perfection that left me with a big smile on my face.  This place isn't cheap and the service isn't the four seasons.  However, if you want authentic Italian food in SF this is your place.  5 Stars.
author: Raymond F.

description: One of the best meals I've experienced in North Beach.  It was genuinely a wonderful meal.  I had the pea puree with prociutto on crostini and the duck livers with polenta.  The duck liver was perfect, sauteed with caramelized onions and a touch of bacon.  The crostini was the best thing either of us had.  My date had the grilled asparagus and the lamb shank for a main course.  The lamb was wonderful.  We simply put our wine choice in Flora's hands and she poured a great glass of italian wine that complemented the meal perfectly.    The restaurant setting is perfect for an anniversary such as ours.   I'll go back for any special occasion.
author: Timothy H.

description:
This is one of those places you will never know about unless someone tells you.  I walked by it probably 50 times and never knew it was there, or that it turns out in my opinion the best Italian (Venetian) cuisine in the city.  Really a terrific spot, magnified by the sea of stale, unimpressive, under-performing touristy restaurants in which it resides.

Flora (the owner) and the other staff have never been anything but completely nice to me and others I know who have been here.  If you're expecting warm, chatty service you won't get it -- but if you want friendly, polite and knowledgeable staff that is what you will get.  I have read here and elsewhere that certain things seem to irk the owner (e.g. showing up with small kids, paying by credit card instead of cash, etc.).  But, I have never experienced any of this, and imagine they are either (1) based on only a small amount of truth, or (2) were posted by restaurant-goers who lack at least a certain amount of basic courtesy and respect.  Flora and her staff really are passionate about making terrific food, which comes through in everything in the restaurant.  As everyone says, you have to try the gnocchi, but you really can't go wrong with the ever changing handwritten menu.  Just ask Flora and you will not be led astray.  This is a place you can take a true San Franciscan, and you just might impress them with a terrific restaurant they never knew existed.  While not cheap, this place is a great value when you consider the quality of the ingredients and the taste of the end product.
author: Jeff L.

description: The gnocchi appetizer is the best in the city, bar none.  The owner Flora is also very nice and da Flora is what makes North Beach what it is.
author: Joe K.

description: We took a friend here for a birthday dinner at the end of February and had a really great meal. I ordered the sweet potato gnocchi, and they were creamy and deliciousas promised. What was even better was the linguini with onions and anchovies. Amazing! I've been trying to recreate it for the past two weeks with no success. Also great: the porchetta tonnato and the risotto with spring vegetables. The wine list was incredibly extensive and our server helped us pick out an outstanding red that matched all four of our very different dishes. Great service, funky decor. All of us agreed it was a terrific meal, and we'd definitely go back!
author: Damon M.

description: Great food. Actually, the only good Italian food I've ever had in North Beach. The sweet potato gnocchi is definitely not to be missed--little pillows of heaven. A little more wine (great list and very helpful advice from Flora) and I would have licked the plate clean. Everyone is eager to answer any and all questions, but overall, the service is just kinda weird. The owner is incredibly knowledgeable but definitely a little rough around the edges. It was immediately apparent what most of the other posters were talking about. Still, I'll go back, and I'll get a double order of gnocchi.
author: Heather S.

description: As other reviewers have described, the service here is extremely unwelcoming and is not worth the food. My boyfriend and I went here for an anniversary dinner on a weekday and had made reservations well in advance. We are young, in our twenties, and Asian and I could not help feeling discriminated against. As soon as we entered the restaurant, we were immediately told there were no openings left for dinner and were asked to leave. When we mentioned we had reservations, the staff was hesitant (thought there were tables open for two) and we had to wait about 10 min before being seated. Our table was the only one without a tablecloth and we were the only guests that did not receive bread. When we asked about this, the waiter eventually brought bread and apologized for the tablecloth but did not offer us another table with one. I was also given a snobby, impatient look from the owner when I asked about a dish. The food was good but needless to say, my boyfriend and I were left with a bad aftertaste.
author: Alisa T.

description: I visited this neighborhood restaurant about a year ago. This one definitely made it into our list-- the never-go-again list. Worst attidute, worst (outright bad) wine, and just so-so food. We complained about the wine, and the response: the lady just walks away! Not a word. They never once asked how the food was. Like another reviewer, we also felt like others were treated better--probably the regulars. What I don't understand is, how can someone be a regular in this place? I've done my share of restaurants in life, and believe me, I can tell a good one when I see one. If you want good Italian food, stay away from here.
author: ofelia R.

description: This is the place! Classic North Beach setting with an intimate dining room. Great wine list and incredible "custom-designed and hand-made" Northern Italian food. The service is very personnel and also helpful with selections and recommendations. Make sure that you try the gnocchi! We had a very relaxing and enjoyable time and will go back, for sure.
author: William W.

description: one very rainy night I stumbled into Da Flora with my daughter.  We'd never heard of the place but we toasted our good fortune - every course was delicious, including the wine.  Then, sadly, we made reservations and treated some friends on a Friday night.  It's was crowded and maybe a little understaffed and overbooked.  Food arrived lukewarm and some dishes were just - eh. The waiter was nice but kept forgetting to bring water etc.  Finally, one of us had to leave the table and chase the waiter down.   anyway - every restaurant can have a bad night on occasion.  we still love this place and we'll still recommend it....but perhaps not on a Friday or Saturday night.
author: aidan f.

description: wow, great food and service.  nice little spot that is worth a second trip.  we were seated without an issue at around 8pm, however people about an hour later were not seated.  it seems to be all about timing and maybe presentation/manners when you arrive as this spot is only open three hours a night
author: Tim G.

description: Let me start by saying I don't usually take the time to review restaurants, but the service and food quality here was so poor I didn't want someone else to have the kind of despicable experience we had. From the minute we walked in the door (on time and with a reservation) we were treated like second class citizens. Flora (nicknamed the sea witch) was grungy, unkept and rude. She asked us to wait outside while she waited for a chair to open up because she had run out. When we asked for the rigatoni, she informed us that they were out out and had replaced it with a delicious ravioli. When I asked her how many raviolis come with the dish she told me she didn't have time to find out. They served us the wrong wine, the food was totally bland, they never came by the table. Flora seemed only interested in the regulars. (Regulars? who would put up with this treatment and poor quality more than once?) Do yourself a favor and skip this hell hole.

description: This place was very mediocre. A friend recommended it as her favorite Italian restaurant in the city, and I see that many Yelpers agree. My husband and I went on a Wednesday around 6 p.m. When we entered, there were 2 other parties there, but by the time we left the place was packed. Even with only 2 other parties, service was very slow. Water and bread took a very long time to come. The entrees came very quickly after our orders were taken. I thought their foccacia bread was excellent - maybe the best I've ever tasted. Their homemade tagliatelli, however, was a different story. It was very, very soft - I think they overcooked it by a few minutes because it was soggy. The flavor was mild. My husband got the penne, which was much better, but it was not unique in any way. The bill for the two of us, with no drink, no appetizers, and a shared dessert, was over $50. The food was absolutely not worth that.
